questions.text: Which of the following is a technology-based surveillance system for tuberculosis (TB) in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nikshay

  • Nikshay is a web-based solution for monitoring the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP) and the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) in India. It is a Health Management Information System (HMIS) - an online software for reporting & compliance with treatment.

Incorrect Options:

Nischay (Option B): Nischay Kits are home-based UPT testing kits provided free by Asha

DOTS 99 (Option C): DOTS 99 is a toll-free number written below anti-TB tablets to ensure the continuity of the treatment. The patients in the continuation phase are expected to call the Toll-free number when they take the medicine.

DOTS (Option D): Directly Observed Treatment Short course involves the direct observation of patients taking their TB medication during the intensive phase by a healthcare worker.

questions.text: A gym owner observes that individuals who drink iced tea during their workouts tend to lose more weight. What is the nature of this relationship?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Indirect

Explanation:

  • In this case, weight loss (outcome) is not directly caused by drinking iced tea (independent variable). A third factor could influence both, like the workout itself.
  • Also, these individuals might be more health-conscious overall, engage in more vigorous workouts, or follow a better diet, which facilitates their weight loss.

Types of Association:

Type of Association

Description

Spurious (Option A)

An association that appears to be present but is actually due to chance or an error in data.

If the gym owner's observation was spurious, it would mean that the association between iced tea consumption and weight loss is completely false and exists due to some error in observation or data collection.

Indirect (Option D)

An association in which a third variable (known as the confounding variable) causes both the predictor and the outcome.

Direct (Causal)  (Option C)

An association where the predictor directly influences the outcome.

 

If the relationship between iced tea consumption and weight loss were direct, it would mean that drinking iced tea itself leads to weight loss. However, it is unlikely that drinking iced tea alone would have a direct effect on weight loss.

a. One-to-One causal

A direct causal link between a single predictor and a single outcome.

b. Multifactorial

An association involving multiple factors contributing to the outcome.

Relative (Option B): This would imply a comparison between two things, but doesn't directly address the relationship type.

questions.text: A study was conducted in 3 states to measure the mean blood pressure in each community. Health workers were assigned to visit each house in the 3 communities. The mean blood pressure of each community was then compared. What is the study design called?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Cross sectional

  • A cross-sectional study involves observing a defined population at a single point in time or over a short period. In this scenario, health workers measured the mean blood pressure of each community at one point in time, making it a cross-sectional study.

Cross-sectional studies:

  • Observations are done only once in the population.
  • Carried over a given point of time or period of time.
  • This helps to find out the existence of both old and new cases (Prevalence rate).
  • This does not help to study the natural history of the disease and the risk factors.
  • This is not time-consuming, not difficult, and cheap.

Incorrect Options:

Case-control (Option A): A case-control study compares individuals who have a specific condition (cases) with individuals who do not have the condition (controls).

Cohort (Option C): A cohort study follows a group of people over time to see how their exposures affect their outcomes.

Ecological study (Option D): An ecological study examines the relationships between exposure and outcome at the population or group level rather than the individual level.

questions.text: Wasting in a child is assessed by which of the following measures?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Weight-for-height

Explanation:

  • Weight-for-height is a key indicator used to assess wasting in a child. Wasting refers to a child who has a low weight compared to their height, indicating acute undernutrition.
    • Weight-for-height assesses acute malnutrition (wasting).
    • Height-for-age assesses chronic malnutrition (stunting).
    • Weight-for-age is an overall indicator but does not differentiate between acute and chronic malnutrition, making it less specific for either.
    • Head circumference is a general indicator that can reflect both acute and chronic malnutrition, but it's not the primary marker for either.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not the key indicators for wasting.

questions.text: In the context of a new onset of a morbid disease, how does the change in incidence affect the prevalence of the disease?

choices.text: Prevalence is not related to incidence
Incidence will increase, and prevalence will decrease
Prevalence will increase with a decrease in the incidence

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Incidence and prevalence will increase:

  • When a new morbid disease appears, the number of new cases (incidence) will increase. As a result, more individuals will have the disease at any given time, contributing to an increase in prevalence.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: The Anemia Mukt Bharat program aims to address anemia across India through targeted interventions. Which statement accurately describes its administration of Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation?

choices.text: IFA is provided during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues during lactation for up to 6 months
IFA supplementation is administered solely during pregnancy
A 100-day course of IFA supplementation is sufficient
Administering IFA during the 1st trimester is adequate.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A- IFA is provided during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues during lactation for up to 6 months

 

  • The Anemia Mukt Bharat program includes comprehensive IFA supplementation that begins during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues through lactation for up to 6 months.
  • Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation:
    • 5-9 year children: Weekly 1 IFA - 45 mg. of Fe + 400 mcg. of folic acid, sugar coated - pink color. Biannual deworming with one tablet of Albendazole tablet 400 mg done during the National Deworming days once in 6 months (10 of Aug and 10 of Feb of every year)
    • Adolescent boys and girls - weekly 1 IFA - containing 100 mg Fe and 500 mcg of folic acid and biannual deworming with 1 tablet of 400 mg Albendazole.
    • Pregnant women: starts in 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues through lactation for up to 6 months.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect as IFA is provided during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy and continues during lactation for up to 6 months.

questions.text: In a population with a total of 4050 births, there are 50 stillbirths, 50 neonatal deaths within the first 7 days, and 150 deaths between 8 and 28 days of life. What is the Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) for this population?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- 50

Explanation:

Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) measures the number of deaths of infants within the first 28 days of life per 1000 live births.

It is calculated as,

Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) = (No. of deaths of children (neonates) 0 – 28 days of life / live births) x 1000)

Calculate Live Births:

  • Live births = Total births - stillbirths
  • Live births = 4050 - 50 = 4000

Determine the Total Number of Neonatal Deaths:

  • Neonatal deaths include deaths within the first 7 days and between 8 and 28 days.
  • Total neonatal deaths = 50 (deaths within the first 7 days) + 150 (deaths between 8 and 28 days) = 200

Calculate NMR:

NMR = (200/4000) x 1000 = 50

questions.text: What is the WHO definition of blindness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- 3/60

Explanation:

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as a visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction.

Distance vision impairment (WHO):

  • Mild – visual acuity worse than 6/12
  • Moderate – visual acuity worse than 6/18 (Option C)
  • Severe – visual acuity worse than 6/60 (Option A)
  • Blindness – visual acuity worse than 3/60 (Option B)

1/60 (Option D): 1/60 is not the specific cut-off point defined by the WHO for blindness.

questions.text:
Calculate relative risk for the given situation:


	
		
			
			 
			
			
			Exposed to malaria
			
			
			Not exposed to malaria
			
		
		
			
			Vaccinated
			
			
			6
			
			
			94
			
		
		
			
			Non-vaccinated
			
			
			12
			
			
			88
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- 0.5

Explanation:

Relative risk = Incidence in Vaccinated / Incidence in Non-Vaccinated

Relative risk (RR):

Incidence in Vaccinated (Exposed to Malaria):

  • Number of vaccinated individuals exposed: 6
  • Total vaccinated individuals: 6 (exposed) + 94 (not exposed) = 100
  • Incidence in vaccinated = 6/100 = 0.06 (or 60/1000)

 

Incidence in Non-Vaccinated (Exposed to Malaria):

  • Number of non-vaccinated individuals exposed: 12
  • Total non-vaccinated individuals: 12 (exposed) + 88 (not exposed) = 100
  • Incidence in non-vaccinated = 12/100 = 0.12 (or 120/1000)

Relative Risk (RR):

  • RR = Incidence in Vaccinated / Incidence in Non-Vaccinated
  • RR = 0.06 / 0.12 = 0.5

questions.text: What is the typical Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) in a healthy adult?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 125 ml/min

Explanation:

  • This is the typical GFR for a healthy adult. GFR measures how well the kidneys are filtering blood. A rate of 125 ml/min reflects optimal kidney function and is considered normal.

Glomerular Filtration Rate:

  • GFR is the rate at which plasma is filtered by the glomeruli in the kidneys.
  • It is a key indicator of kidney function, as it shows how efficiently the kidneys are filtering wastes from the blood.
  • The normal GFR range is around 90-120 ml/min/1.73 m² for most adults, but 125 ml/min is considered the standard average for a healthy individual.
  • The formula to calculate GFR is:
    • GFR=Net Filtration Pressure (NFP)×Filtration Coefficient (Kf)
    • Net Filtration Pressure (NFP) is determined by the difference between the hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries and the opposing pressures in the Bowman’s capsule and the colloid osmotic pressure of the blood.
    • Filtration Coefficient (Kf) depends on the surface area and permeability of the glomerular capillaries.

Factors affecting GFR include:

  • Renal Blood Flow: Increased blood flow boosts GFR, while decreased blood flow reduces it.
  • Hydrostatic and Osmotic Pressures: High glomerular capillary pressure increases GFR, whereas high pressure in Bowman’s capsule or elevated colloid osmotic pressure decreases it.
  • Constriction of Afferent and Efferent Arterioles: Constriction of afferent arterioles reduces GFR, while constriction of efferent arterioles can increase GFR.
  • Hormonal and Neural Controls: Various hormones like angiotensin II and conditions like sympathetic nervous system activation can modulate GFR by affecting blood flow and pressure within the kidneys.

questions.text: How does the muscle spindle detect muscle length during muscle contraction?

choices.text: Stretch receptor in the muscle belly

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stretch receptor in the muscle belly

Explanation: The muscle spindle is a specialized sensory receptor located within the muscle belly. It detects changes in muscle length (stretch) and velocity to asses the joint's position.

Muscle spindle receptor

  • Muscle spindles are sensory receptors located within the bulk of skeletal muscles, specifically within the muscle belly.
  • They are spindle-shaped and play a crucial role in detecting changes in muscle length and velocity, which helps in sensing the position of joints.

Structure of muscle spindles:

  • Intrafusal fibers:
    • These are the specialized muscle fibers that make up the muscle spindle.
    • Unlike typical muscle fibers, they are non-contractile in the central region and are surrounded by a capsule.
    • Intrafusal fibers are red due to their high mitochondrial content.
  • Extrafusal fibers:
    • Surrounding the muscle spindles, these are the standard contractile fibers of the skeletal muscle.
    • They are white and responsible for generating force and movement.

Function:

  • Length detection:
    • Muscle spindles detect changes in muscle length.
    • When a muscle is stretched, the muscle spindle is also stretched, which activates the sensory nerve endings within the spindle.
  • Velocity detection:
    • The spindles can also detect the rate of change of muscle length (velocity of stretch), providing important information for maintaining posture and coordinating movements.

Stretch receptor on the tendon (Option A): The Golgi tendon organ, not a muscle spindle, is located in the tendon and detects changes in muscle tension rather than length. ​

Golgi tendon organ (Option C): As mentioned, this organ detects muscle tension and not length. ​

Mechanoreceptor in the joint capsule (Option D): These receptors detect changes in joint position and pressure but do not directly monitor muscle length during contraction.

questions.text: Which substance inhibits the iron transporter on the basal side of the enterocyte?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hepcidin

Explanation:

  • This is a peptide hormone produced by the liver that regulates iron homeostasis.
  • It inhibits ferroportin, which is the iron transporter on the basal side of the enterocyte, thereby decreasing iron absorption and release into the bloodstream.

Iron homeostasis:

  • Dietary Iron conversion and absorption:
    • Most dietary iron is in the ferric (Fe³⁺) form, which needs to be converted to the ferrous (Fe²⁺) form to be absorbed.
    • Gastric secretions and reductase enzymes on the brush border of enterocytes reduce Fe³⁺ to Fe²⁺.
  • Iron absorption mechanism:
    • Iron absorption mainly occurs in the duodenum.
    • Fe²⁺ is absorbed by enterocytes via divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1)
    • Within enterocytes, some Fe²⁺ is stored in ferritin, while the rest is exported into the bloodstream by ferroportin 1 (FPN1). (Option D)
    • Hephaestin, a ferroxidase enzyme, facilitates the conversion of Fe²⁺ to Fe³⁺ as it is transported across the basolateral membrane.
  • Iron transport and storage:
    • Once in the plasma, Fe²⁺ is oxidized back to Fe³⁺ and binds to transferrin.
    • Transferrin transports iron to various tissues, where it is stored primarily in the form of ferritin and hemosiderin. (Option C)
      • Ferritin: A soluble protein complex that stores iron safely within cells, particularly in the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and intestinal mucosa. (Option B)
      • Hemosiderin: A more stable and less soluble iron-storage complex found mainly in macrophages, especially under conditions of iron overload.
  • Role of Hepcidin: (Option A)
    • Hepcidin, a peptide hormone produced by the liver, regulates iron levels by binding to ferroportin (FPN1).
    • The binding of hepcidin to ferroportin leads to the internalization and degradation of ferroportin.
    • This process reduces the export of iron from enterocytes, macrophages, and hepatocytes into the bloodstream, thereby decreasing serum iron levels.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the Emergency Room following a road traffic accident (RTA) with thoracic and abdominal injuries. The patient is found to be in hypovolemic shock. What is the most probable cause of the decreased cardiac output in this case?

choices.text: Decrease in contractility of the heart

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Decrease in preload

Explanation:

  • In hypovolemic shock, the body loses a significant amount of blood or fluids, leading to a decrease in circulating blood volume.
  • This reduction in blood volume results in a decreased preload — the amount of blood returning to the heart.

Types of shock:

Types of shock

Pathophysiology

Causes

Cardiac output

Cardiogenic

(Option B)

 

Inadequate pumping of the heart due to myocardial function.
  • Acute myocardial infarction
  • Heart failure
  • Cardiac arrhythmias

 

↓

Hypovolemic

Decreased amount of fluid in the vascular system
  • Acute hemorrhage
  • Burn
  • Metabolic: adrenal insufficiency, diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Severe diarrhea or vomiting.

 

↓

Distributive

Sudden increase in the vascular compartment capacity due to acute marked vasodilation
  • Neurogenic shock
  • Anaphylactic shock
  • Septic shock

 

↓

Obstructive

Obstruction to the ejection of blood from the ventricle
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Cardiac tumor
  • Tension pneumothorax

 

↓

Increase in preload (Option C): This is incorrect because in hypovolemic shock, preload is actually decreased due to fluid loss, not increased.

Increase in afterload (Option D): Although increased afterload can affect cardiac output, in the context of hypovolemic shock, the immediate cause of decreased cardiac output is the reduction in preload due to reduced blood volume.

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the role of a second messenger in cellular signaling?

choices.text: Directly interacts with the cell's DNA

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Modulate intracellular hormone response

Explanation:

  • Second messengers are molecules that relay signals received at cell surface receptors to target molecules inside the cell, leading to a physiological response.
  • They play a crucial role in modulating intracellular processes after a signal (such as a hormone or neurotransmitter) binds to a cell surface receptor.
  • These messengers help amplify and propagate the signal within the cell, triggering responses such as gene expression, enzyme activation, or changes in cell metabolism.

Examples of second messengers include cyclic AMP (cAMP), inositol trisphosphate (IP3), and calcium ions (Ca²⁺).

Pathway

Activation

Key Enzymes

Key Second Messengers

Cellular Effects

Adenylyl Cyclase

GPCR-Gs binding

Adenylyl Cyclase

cAMP

Protein phosphorylation, e.g., thyroid hormones, adrenocortical steroids

Phospholipase C

GPCR binding

Phospholipase C

IP3, DAG

Calcium mobilization, smooth muscle contraction, protein phosphorylation

Act on extracellular receptors (Option A): Second messengers do not act directly on extracellular receptors. Instead, they work intracellularly after a receptor on the cell surface has been activated.

Modulate extracellular hormone response (Option B): Second messengers do not affect the extracellular hormone response; their function is to relay and amplify the signal inside the cell after the hormone binds to its receptor.

Directly interacts with the cell’s DNA (Option D): Second messengers do not directly interact with DNA. Instead, they influence cellular processes through various pathways, such as activating kinases or other signaling molecules, which then affect DNA indirectly.

questions.text: What renal function is represented by the formula UV/P?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Clearance

Explanation:

  • The formula UV/P, where U is the concentration of a substance in the urine, V is the urine flow rate, and P is the concentration of the substance in the plasma, represents the renal clearance of that substance.
  • It quantifies the volume of plasma from which the substance is completely removed per unit time.

Clearance measures the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per minute (mL/min), reflecting renal excretory efficiency. It is essential for evaluating kidney function, including filtration, reabsorption, and secretion processes.

To calculate the clearance rate (Cs) of the substance, use the formula:

Clearance Formula: (Cs) = (Us x V) / Ps

Us: Urine concentration of the substance

V: Urine flow rate

Ps: Plasma concentration of the substance

Types of Clearance Measurements:

Inulin Clearance
  • Used to measure Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted.
  • Not ideal for routine use due to intravenous administration.

Creatinine Clearance
  • Estimates GFR using creatinine, which is primarily filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Slightly inaccurate due to tubular secretion, but practical for clinical settings.

PAH Clearance
  • Estimates Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).
  • PAH is cleared through both glomerular filtration and tubular secretion.
  • Correction for PAH extraction ratio improves accuracy.

Filtration (Option A): This process refers to the initial filtration of blood through the glomerulus to form filtrate. The formula ​ does not measure this process directly.

Tubular Secretion (Option B): This is the process by which substances are actively transported from the blood into the renal tubules. The formula does not specifically measure tubular secretion.

Tubular Reabsorption (Option C): This refers to the process of reabsorbing substances from the renal tubules back into the blood. The formula ​ does not measure reabsorption directly.

questions.text: Identify the fracture shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Radial head fracture

Explanation:

  • The given X-ray image depicts radial head fracture which is evident by the marked indentation at the site of Radial head.
  • Radial head fracture is caused mostly due to indirect trauma, with most resulting from a fall on an abducted arm with minimal or moderate flexion of the elbow joint.

Radial Head Fractures:

Definition
  • A fracture of the radial head, the upper part of the radius that articulates with the humerus and ulna at the elbow joint.

Causes
  • Most commonly caused by a fall onto an outstretched hand (FOOSH)
  • Direct trauma or a blow to the elbow
  • MVA (Motor Vehicle Accidents) or sports injuries

Types of Fractures
  • Type I: Non-displaced fracture (usually treated conservatively)
  • Type II: Displaced fracture with a single fragment (may require surgical intervention)
  • Type III: Comminuted (multiple fragments, often requiring surgical reconstruction or replacement)

Symptoms
  • Pain and tenderness at the lateral aspect of the elbow
  • Swelling and bruising around the elbow joint
  • Limited range of motion, with flexion and extension
  • Difficulty supination and pronation

Diagnosis
  • Tenderness, swelling, and limited motion.
  • X-rays: Used to classify the type and displacement of the fracture.
  • CT scan: Used for more complex fractures.

Treatment Options
  • Conservative management: For non-displaced (Type I) fractures.
  • Surgical management: For displaced (Type II) or comminuted (Type III) fractures- radial head fixation, replacement (arthroplasty), or excision.

Complications
  • Loss of elbow range of motion
  • Chronic pain
  • Elbow instability
  • Post-traumatic arthritis
  • Stiffness or deformity of the joint

Option B, C and D - Elbow fracture, Medial and Lateral epicondyle fracture:

  • Fractures around elbow includes:
    • Supracondylar fracture
    • Medial epicondyle fracture
    • Lateral epicondyle fracture
  • These structures are seen intact in the given X-ray image.

questions.text: Identify the fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Lateral epicondyle fracture

Explanation:

Fracture of the Lateral Condyle of the Humerus:

Definition
  • A fracture involving the lateral condyle of the humerus. It is typically seen in children.

Causes
  • Most commonly by direct trauma to the elbow (Fall on the outstretched hand or a direct blow).
  • Torsional forces during activity or sports.

Types of Fractures
  • Type I: Non-displaced fractures (usually treated conservatively).
  • Type II: Displaced fractures (may require surgical intervention).
  • Type III: Comminuted fractures with significant displacement (often require surgery).

Symptoms
  • Pain and swelling around the lateral aspect of the elbow.
  • Limited range of motion, especially during extension and rotation.
  • Deformity or abnormal positioning of the elbow joint (in more severe cases).
  • Tenderness over the lateral condyle.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical examination: History of trauma, swelling, and deformity.
  • X-rays: To assess fracture type and displacement. Lateral and AP views are commonly taken.
  • CT scan: Can help evaluate complex fractures or assess joint involvement.

Treatment Options
  • Non-displaced fractures (Type I): Conservative management with rest, ice, and a sling or cast for immobilization.
  • Displaced fractures (Type II): Require surgical fixation, such as the use of pins or screws.
  • Comminuted fractures (Type III): Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF).

Complications
  • Elbow stiffness or loss of range of motion.
  • Malunion or improper healing, leading to angular deformity.
  • Post-traumatic arthritis due to joint surface involvement.
  • Nerve injury (Radial nerve) due to fracture or surgical intervention.

Medial epicondyle fracture (Option B) in the given X-ray image is intact

Supracondylar fracture (Option C) The X-ray image shows the intact supracondylar region of the humerus. It is most common in children. The Clinical features are S-shaped deformity, Dimple sign and X-ray signs: Fat pad sign, Teardrop sign, Fish tail sign, Crescent sign

Infracondyle fracture (Option D) Infracondyle is seen in the femur bone.

questions.text: Identify the given organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Epidermophyton Floccosum

Explanation:

  • The given image represents club shaped macroconidia of Epidermophyton. The given organism is Epidermophyton floccosum. This is a dermatophyte, a type of fungus that causes skin infections, specifically on the hair, skin, and nails. It is known for its role in tinea infections such as athlete's foot and other superficial skin infections.

Classification by Genus

Genus

Key Characteristics

Microsporum

Predominantly macroconidia; spindle-shaped, multicellular structures; infects hair and skin.

Trichophyton

More abundant microconidia in clusters; macroconidia are thin, and elongated; include species like T. rubrum which is common in humans. Infects hair, nails and skin.

Epidermophyton

Lacks microconidia; club-shaped, multicellular macroconidia; infects skin and nails but not hair.

 

Features

Trichophyton

Microsporum

Epidermophyton

1. Site of infection

Hair, nail, and skin

Hair and skin only

Skin and nail only

2. Colony

Powdery pigmented

Cotton-like pigmented

Powdery greenish yellow

3. Spores

a. Microconidia

Abundant

Relatively scanty

Absent

b. Macroconidia

Pencil or cylindrical-shaped

(Option D ruled out)

Spindle-shaped

(Option A & B ruled out)

Club or pear-shaped

Types of Conidia

  • Microconidia: Small, unicellular conidia.
  • Macroconidia: Larger, multicellular, septate conidia.

Classification by Habitat

Dermatophytes are further classified by their natural habitats:

Habitat Type

Characteristics

Examples

Anthropophilic

Primarily found in humans; causes mild, chronic lesions.

T. rubrum, E. floccosum, M. audouinii

Zoophilic

Natural parasites of animals; cause severe inflammation but are treatable.

T. verrucosum, M. canis

Geophilic

Found in soil; less pathogenic to humans.

M. gypseum, T. ajelloi

questions.text: The diagnosis in a patient who is unable to do internal and external rotation of the hip is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Dislocation of the hip

Explanation:

The attitude of the lower limb in the dislocation of the hip is flexed, adducted and fully internally rotated which makes it impossible for further internal or external rotation of the hip.

Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:
Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Radiological Features:

  • Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken.
  • May require a CT scan for associated fractures.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

 

Femur Head Fracture (Option A) may affect hip movement, it doesn't specifically cause a loss of both internal and external rotation as prominently as a dislocation

Acetabular Fractures (Option B) may not result in an absolute inability to perform internal and external rotation unless they are associated with significant displacement or damage to the surrounding structures.

Pelvic Fracture (Option D does not typically cause a complete loss of internal and external rotation of the hip, unless there is concurrent injury to the hip joint itself.

questions.text: Relative bradycardia is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Brucella

Explanation:

  • Relative bradycardia refers to a situation where the heart rate is slower than expected for the degree of fever. It is often seen in infections like Brucellosis, which is caused by the Brucella bacteria. Even though the patient may have a fever, the heart rate is not as fast as would be expected in such a febrile state.

Brucella features:

  • Brucella melitensis is the most pathogenic species for humans.

Characteristics of Brucella:

Morphology

Biochemical Properties

Growth & Susceptibility

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli

Catalase positive

Do not grow well on standard laboratory media

Non-capsulated and non-spore forming

Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis)

Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 minutes

Often exhibit a bipolar staining appearance

Urease positive

Killed by 1% phenol in 15 minutes
 

Utilize oxygen but do not typically ferment carbohydrates

Killed by pasteurization

Zoonotic Nature: Primarily affects goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, and pigs. Humans can become infected through contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated animal products

Clinical Presentation in Humans:

  • Symptoms: Intermittent fever, loss of appetite, nausea, muscular and articular pains, fatigue, sweating, relative bradycardia and joint pain
  • Also known as Undulant fever, Mediterranean fever, Maltese fever
  • Diagnosis is challenging due to nonspecific symptoms and relies on high clinical suspicion

Diagnosis of Brucellosis:

Laboratory Testing Methods:

  • Blood Culture:
    • Most definitive diagnostic method
    • Requires trypticase soy broth or brucella broth in biphasic blood culture bottles (e.g., Castaneda method)
    • Large blood volume (5 ml) recommended due to low bacterial load
    • Incubation at 37°C under 5-10% CO2 for at least 6-8 weeks
    • Positive in approximately 30-50% of cases
    • Bone marrow cultures may have a higher yield
  • Serological Tests:
    • Used when culture methods are unsuccessful

Serological Test Types:

Test

Description

Key Points

Standard Agglutination Test (SAT)

Tube agglutination test using serial dilutions of patient's serum and killed B. abortus antigen
  • Significant titer: 160 or more.
  • Acute brucellosis titer: 640 or more within 3-4 weeks.
  • Prozone phenomenon common.
  • False positives with cholera, tularemia, yersinia infection, or immunization

Complement Fixation Test

Detects IgG antibodies
  • Valuable in chronic cases

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay)

Distinguishes between IgM and IgG antibodies
  • Useful for differentiating acute from chronic infections

Rapid Tests

Includes rapid dipstick tests and Rose Bengal card test
  • Quick results.
  • Can be used for initial screening

Treatment of Brucellosis:

  • Antibiotics:
    • Standard treatment for adults: Doxycycline for 45 days and intramuscular streptomycin daily for the first two weeks
    • Children: Cotrimoxazole with rifampicin or gentamycin

Incorrect Options:

Dengue (Option A): Dengue fever typically causes a high fever, but it is not particularly associated with relative bradycardia. In fact, tachycardia (increased heart rate) can often be seen.

Bordetella (Option C): The bacteria Bordetella causes whooping cough (pertussis), which typically involves paroxysmal coughing, but not relative bradycardia.

Leptospirosis (Option D): This infection, caused by Leptospira bacteria, is characterized by fever, liver and kidney dysfunction, and other symptoms, but relative bradycardia is not a typical feature.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is associated with which cellular organelle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Peroxisomes

Explanation

  • Zellweger syndrome is a peroxisomal biogenesis disorder caused by mutations in PEX genes.
  • It results in defective peroxisome formation, leading to an inability to metabolize very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) and plasmalogens.
  • Clinical features include hypotonia, seizures, hepatomegaly, and craniofacial abnormalities.

 

Zellweger Spectrum Disorder

  • Rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective peroxisome biogenesis affecting VLCFA metabolism.
  • Includes Zellweger syndrome, neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy, infantile Refsum disease, and rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata.

Etiology
  • Caused by mutations in PEX genes encoding peroxins, primarily PEX1/PEX6
  • Functional peroxisomal disturbances:
    1. Zellweger spectrum: Generalized peroxisomal dysfunction.
    2. Adrenoleukodystrophy: Mutations in ABCD1, impacting VLCFA transport.
    3. Rhizomelic chondrodysplasia punctata: Multiple enzymatic defects.

Pathophysiology
  • Peroxisomes: Membrane-bound organelles with >50 enzymes for fatty acid metabolism, abundant in liver/kidney.
  • Mutated PEX genes disrupt peroxisome formation, leading to VLCFA accumulation, reduced steroid biosynthesis, and neuronal damage.
  • Major abnormalities:
    • Brain: Demyelination, neuronal injury.
    • Liver: Fibrosis.
    • Kidney: Cortical cysts.

Clinical Features

Multisystem involvement with severity depending on age of onset:

  • Neonatal-Infantile: Hypotonia, feeding issues, seizures, facial dysmorphism, ocular and hearing abnormalities, hepatomegaly.
  • Childhood: Developmental delay, FTT, hepatic dysfunction, adrenal insufficiency, neuroregression.
  • Adolescent-Adult: Neuroregression, ataxia, neuropathy, adrenal insufficiency, leukodystrophy.

Diagnosis
  • Initial: Clinical features + elevated VLCFA on newborn screening.
  • Biochemical tests: Elevated VLCFA, bile acid intermediates, and phytanic/pristanic acid; reduced plasmalogens.
  • Genetic testing: Confirms PEX mutations.
  • Prenatal diagnosis and genetic counseling recommended.

Management
  • No cure; supportive care focuses on improving quality of life.

 

Therapies:

  1. Docosahexaenoic acid
  2. Lorenzo oil: Reduces VLCFA but doesn't halt disease progression.
  3. Cholic acid: Approved for hepatic dysfunction.

 

Supportive Measures:

  • Hearing aids for hearing loss.
  • Ophthalmologic care for vision issues.
  • Antiepileptics for seizures.
  • Vitamin supplementation: Fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K).
  • Cortisone for adrenal insufficiency.
  • Gastrostomy for feeding difficulties.

 

Nucleosomes (Option B): Disorders involving nucleosomes are linked to chromatin remodeling or epigenetic regulation, not Zellweger syndrome.

Lysosomes (Option C): Lysosomal storage diseases (e.g., Tay-Sachs disease, Gaucher disease) result from enzyme deficiencies affecting lysosomal function. Zellweger syndrome does not involve lysosomes.

Ribosomes (Option D): Diseases involving ribosomes include ribosomopathies like Diamond-Blackfan anemia, which are unrelated to Zellweger syndrome.

questions.text: Identify the structure pointed in the anatomical snuff box.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Extensor pollicis brevis

Explanation: The marked structure is Extensor pollicis brevis

Anatomical snuff box/Radial fossa: Triangular hollow visible on the lateral aspect of the wrist when the thumb is fully extended.

Boundaries:

  • Anterolateral: Extensor pollicis brevis, Abductor pollicis longus
  • Posteromedial: Extensor pollicis longus
  • Roof:
    • Dorsal cutaneous branch of radial nerve: Found in the skin and subcutaneous tissue of anatomical snuff box.
    • Cephalic vein: Arises from dorsal venous network of hand and crosses anatomical snuff box to travel to the anterolateral aspect of forearm.

Contents

  • Radial Artery: Crosses the floor of the anatomical snuff box.

Tenderness in the anatomical snuff box following a fall on an outstretched hand strongly suggests a scaphoid fracture, as the scaphoid bone lies in the floor of the anatomical snuff box. This type of fracture is common and can have complications due to poor blood supply.

Adductor pollicis (Option A) muscle is attached to the bases of the 2nd and 3rd metacarpals, capitate, and adjacent carpals and innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. Adducts thumb towards the lateral border of palm.

Flexor pollicis longus (Option C) is one of the deep muscles of the anterior compartment of the forearm and is innervated by the anterior interosseous nerve.

Cephalic vein (Option D) The roof of the anatomical snuff box contains the cephalic vein and the cutaneous branch of the radial nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of watery diarrhea and vomiting. The pathogen exhibited darting motility. Which is the best selective media for the involved pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) TCBS

Explanation:

  • Given the clinical presentation of watery diarrhea and vomiting, the most likely pathogen involved is Vibrio cholerae or another species of the Vibrio genus, which are known to cause gastroenteritis and are characterized by darting motility under the microscope.
  • TCBS agar is a selective culture medium specifically designed for isolating Vibrio species, including Vibrio cholerae. It allows for the growth of alkaline-tolerant bacteria and inhibits the growth of most other enteric bacteria.
  • Colonies of Vibrio cholerae typically appear as yellow on this medium due to sucrose fermentation, making this method highly specific for confirming the diagnosis.

Diagnosis of Vibrio cholerae

Specimen Collection:

  • Preferred Specimen: Stool (mucus flakes)
  • Alternative: Rectal swab if stool is not available
  • Enrichment broth : selenite F broth and alkaline peptone water

Transport Media:

  • VR (Venkatraman Ramakrishnan) media - specific transport media for V. cholera
  • Cary-Blair medium

Microscopy:

  • Morphology: Comma or curved-shaped, reddish Gram-negative bacilli
  • Appearance: Fish-in-stream appearance
  • Motility: Demonstrated by dark field or phase contrast microscopy showing darting motility

Culture:

  • Culture Media and Colony Characteristics:
    • MacConkey Agar: Colorless colonies that may later turn pink due to late fermentation of lactose
    • Blood Agar: Green colonies indicating hemolysis
    • Nutrient Agar: Translucent, round discs with a bluish tinge under transmitted light
    • Gelatin Stab: Infundibuliform (funnel-shaped) or napiform (turnip-shaped) liquefaction

Selective Media:

  • Thiosulfate-Citrate-Bile Salts-Sucrose (TCBS) Agar: (Option B)
    • Differentiates between sucrose fermenters (like Vibrio cholerae) and non-sucrose fermenters (such as Vibrio parahaemolyticus).
    • Vibrio cholerae produces yellow colonies due to sucrose fermentation.

 

Biochemical Reactions:

  • Fermentation: Glucose and sucrose
  • Indole Test: Positive
  • Nitrate Reduction: Nitrates are reduced to nitrites
  • Cholera Red Reaction: Due to nitroso-indole formation
  • Catalase: Positive
  • Oxidase: Positive
  • String Test: A loopful of growth mixed with 0.5% deoxycholate results in string formation

Serological Tests (Not useful for diagnosis)

  • Indirect Hemagglutination
  • Complement- Dependent Vibriocidal Antibody Test

Treatment:

  • Rehydration:
    • Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS)
    • Intravenous (IV) fluids
  • Antibiotics: Secondary treatment

Incorrect Options:

Nutrient media (Option A): This is a general-purpose medium and is not selective, so it wouldn’t be the best choice for isolating Vibrio species.

Cetrimide agar (Option C): This medium is selective for Pseudomonas aeruginosa, not Vibrio species.

Potassium Tellurite Agar (Option D): This is typically used for isolating Corynebacterium diphtheriae, not for Vibrio.

questions.text: Which blood is transfused in a patient with a Bombay blood group?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) O negative

Explanation:

  • The Bombay blood group (hh) is a rare blood type in which the individual lacks the H antigen, which is a precursor for the A and B antigens on red blood cells. This means that a person with the Bombay blood group cannot receive blood from individuals with the typical ABO blood groups (A, B, AB, or O) since their immune system will recognize the A, B, and H antigens as foreign and mount an immune response.
  • Because of this, only O negative blood (which lacks A, B, and H antigens) is compatible for transfusion to a person with the Bombay blood group.

Incorrect Options:

A, B, and AB blood (Option A, B, & C): These all contain the A, B, or both antigens, which a person with the Bombay blood group would react against due to the absence of the H antigen, leading to severe transfusion reactions.

questions.text: What is the composition of lactulose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Galactose + Fructose

Explanation:

  • Lactulose is a synthetic disaccharide composed of galactose and fructose. It is commonly used as a laxative and to treat hepatic encephalopathy.

 

Disaccharide

Sugars present

Linkage

Maltose (Basic thumb rule)

2 glucose residues - glucose + glucose

alpha(1,4)

Isomaltose (Six atoms)

2 glucose residues - glucose + glucose

a(1,6)

Trehalose

2 glucose residues - glucose + glucose

a(1,1)

Sucrose

Glucose + fructose (Option B ruled out)

a(1,2)

Lactose

Galactose + glucose (Option A ruled out)

beta(1,4)

Fructose + Ribulose (Option D): This composition does not correspond to any common disaccharide or sugar.

questions.text: Which of the following microorganisms is likely responsible for causing bilateral infiltrates in an HIV-positive patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pneumocystis Jirovecii

Explanation:

  • In HIV-positive patients, particularly those with a weakened immune system (low CD4 count), Pneumocystis jirovecii is a common cause of bilateral infiltrates in the lungs, leading to Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). PCP is a fungal infection that often presents with symptoms like shortness of breath, cough, and fever, and it typically affects both lungs (bilateral infiltrates).

Pneumocystis jirovecii

Morphology
  1. Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size
  2. Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size
  3. Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size

Risk factors
  • HIV: CD4 < 200
  • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Clinical features

Transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dyspnoea
  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia causing bilateral infiltrates

Diagnosis
  • GMS / Giemsa stain- mc used
  • Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains can demonstrate trophozoites - cyst wall is black with a methenamine silver stain.

 

 

Crushed Ping Pong ball (also called Helmet/Hat or Cup and Saucer appearance).

  • The β-d-glucan test has proven to be quite useful for rapid diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia with a high degree of sensitivity and specificity.

Treatment
  • The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
  • Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate.

Incorrect Options:

Cryptococcus (Option A): This fungal infection can cause meningitis or pulmonary issues in immunocompromised patients but typically presents with a more localized infection rather than bilateral infiltrates.

Histoplasmosis (Option B): While it is a fungal infection common in HIV patients, it typically causes granulomas or localized lung infiltrates, not usually bilateral infiltrates.

Aspergillus (Option D): This fungus can cause lung infections, but it is more likely to cause invasive aspergillosis, which typically presents with a single, more focal lesion rather than bilateral infiltrates.

questions.text: A couple brings their 4-year-old child to the outpatient department (OPD) due to self-mutilating behavior and poor growth. Which of the following associated enzyme deficiencies could explain these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HGPRT deficiency

Explanation

  • Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) deficiency causes Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, a rare X-linked recessive disorder.
  • It is characterized by self-mutilating behavior, hyperuricemia, gout, neurological abnormalities, and poor growth.
  • HGPRT is critical for purine salvage, and its deficiency leads to an overproduction of uric acid.

 

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome

Clinical Features

 
  • Metabolic: Severe gout, sodium urate crystal deposition causing joint swelling and kidney damage.
  • Neurological:
    • Poor muscle control.
    • Involuntary movements (resembling Huntington's disease).
    • Facial grimacing, repetitive limb movements.
  • Behavioral: Self-mutilation (lip and finger biting, starting ~2nd year).
  • Other: Moderate developmental delays, potential megaloblastic anemia (from poor vitamin B12 utilization).

Management
  • Metabolic: Allopurinol for gout; lithotripsy for kidney stones.
  • Neurological: Symptomatic treatment with drugs like carbidopa/levodopa, diazepam, phenobarbital, or haloperidol.

 

Homogentisic Aciduria (Option B): Homogentisic aciduria, or alkaptonuria, results from homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase deficiency. It leads to darkened urine, ochronosis (dark pigmentation of connective tissues), and arthritis but does not cause self-mutilation or poor growth.

Phenylalanine Hydroxylase deficiency (Option C): Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency causes phenylketonuria (PKU), which presents with intellectual disability, seizures, and hypopigmentation. Self-mutilation and hyperuricemia are not associated with this condition.

Adenosine deaminase deficiency (Option D): A rare genetic disorder caused by ADA gene mutations, leading to a lack of B and T lymphocytes and severe immune deficiency. Symptoms, often appearing before 6 months, include recurrent infections, chronic diarrhea, rashes, and delayed growth. Without treatment, life-threatening infections and certain cancers may occur.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby presents with severe hepatomegaly, cataracts in both eyes, lethargy, and hypotonia. Based on these symptoms, which enzyme deficiency is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Galactose-1-Phosphate Uridyl Transferase

Explanation

  • Galactose-1-Phosphate Uridyl Transferase deficiency causes classic galactosemia, a severe metabolic disorder characterized by hepatomegaly, cataracts, lethargy, and hypotonia due to the accumulation of toxic metabolites like galactose-1-phosphate and galactitol.

 

Galactosemia

Enzyme Deficiency
  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase (GALT) - Classical type
  • Galactokinase- benign disease with only oil drop cataract. (Option A ruled out)
  • Epimerase- SNHL + symptoms of classical type

(Low galactose-based diet can be given which is contraindicated in the classical type)

Pathophysiology
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate (toxic causing jaundice, and liver damage)
  • Inability to metabolize galactose from milk
  • Damage to liver, kidney, and brain

Clinical Features
  • Hepatic: Jaundice, hepatomegaly
  • GI: Vomiting, diarrhea, failure to thrive
  • CNS: Seizures, intellectual disability
  • Eyes: Oil drop cataracts
  • Increased risk of E. coli sepsis

Diagnosis
  • Reducing substance in urine (positive)( Positive Benedict test but negative glucose oxidase test)
  • Direct enzyme (GALT) assay
  • Genetic testing (Perinatal diagnosis is possible)

Management
  • Lactose-free diet
  • Breast Milk contraindicated
  • Soy-based or elemental formulas
  • Calcium supplementation

 

Hepatic Glucose-6-Phosphatase (Option C): Deficiency of it causes glycogen storage disease type I (Von Gierke disease), which presents with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, and lactic acidosis. Cataracts are not a feature of this condition.

questions.text: What is the process of converting unconjugated substances into conjugated forms called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glucuronidation

Explanation

  • Glucuronidation is a biochemical process in which a glucuronic acid molecule is attached to a substance, making it more water-soluble and easier to excrete. This process is essential for the detoxification and elimination of substances like bilirubin, drugs, and hormones in the liver.

 

Synthetic Reaction

Description

Examples

Glucuronidation

Conjugation with glucuronic acid via UDP-glucuronosyl transferases (UGTs).

Chloramphenicol, aspirin, paracetamol, morphine, bilirubin, steroid hormones, thyroxine.

Acetylation

Conjugation with acetyl CoA, mediated by N-acetyl transferases.

Isoniazid, sulfonamides, hydralazine, dapsone, clonazepam.

Methylation

Methylation of amines and phenols by methyl transferases using methionine or cysteine as donors.

Adrenaline, histamine, methyldopa, captopril, mercaptopurine.

Sulfation

Conjugation of phenols and steroids with sulfate by sulfotransferases (SULTs).

Chloramphenicol, methyldopa, adrenal steroids.

Glycine Conjugation

Conjugation with glycine for drugs with carboxylic acid groups.

Salicylates, nicotinic acid.

Glutathione Conjugation

Conjugation of reactive intermediates with glutathione via glutathione-S-transferases.

Paracetamol (reactive intermediates), quinones, epoxides.

Ribonucleoside Synthesis

Conjugation for activation of purine and pyrimidine antimetabolites.

Cancer chemotherapeutic agents.

 

Glycation (Option A): Glycation is the non-enzymatic attachment of sugars to proteins or lipids, typically seen in conditions like diabetes. It does not involve the conjugation of substances in the way glucuronidation does.

Glycosylation (Option C): Glycosylation involves the enzymatic attachment of a sugar molecule (often glucose or mannose) to proteins or lipids, typically in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus. It is distinct from glucuronidation and is not primarily involved in detoxification.

Oxidation (Option D): Oxidation refers to the chemical reaction where a molecule loses electrons, often resulting in the addition of oxygen or the removal of hydrogen. While oxidation can modify molecules, it does not specifically refer to the conjugation process like glucuronidation.

questions.text: A patient with a history of strenuous exercise forgot to eat a meal and later consumed alcohol at a party. Which of the following metabolic processes is inhibited by alcohol consumption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gluconeogenesis

Explanation

Alcohol consumption inhibits gluconeogenesis. Alcohol metabolism increases the NADH/NAD+ ratio in the liver, which inhibits key enzymes involved in gluconeogenesis, leading to hypoglycemia, especially in a fasting state after strenuous exercise.

  • Alcohol produces a high NADH/NAD+ ratio in the cytoplasm, the high NADH level favours the conversion of pyruvate to lactate, leading to lactic acidosis.
  • Deficiency of pyruvate leads to inadequate formation of oxaloacetate which blocks gluconeogenesis
  • This results in low blood sugar levels.
  • Symptoms of alcohol-induced hypoglycemia include confusion, irritability, and, in severe cases, loss of consciousness.

 

Glycogenolysis (Option B): Glycogenolysis is generally stimulated by alcohol consumption due to the liver's attempt to maintain glucose levels. While alcohol inhibits gluconeogenesis, it does not directly inhibit glycogenolysis.

HMP shunt (Option C): The hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt is primarily involved in the production of NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate. Alcohol does not directly inhibit this pathway.

Ketone body formation (Option D): Ketone body formation can actually be promoted in alcohol consumption as the body shifts to using fatty acids for energy when glucose is unavailable.

questions.text: What is the preferred management for a pediatric patient with symptomatic adenoid hypertrophy causing chronic nasal obstruction and sleep apnea?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Adenoidectomy

Explanation:

  • The preferred management for a pediatric patient with symptomatic adenoid hypertrophy causing nasal obstruction and sleep apnea is adenoidectomy.

Management of Adenoid Hypertrophy:

Medical Management: (For Mild Cases initially)
  • Breathing exercises
  • Decongestant nasal drops
  • Antihistamines for any nasal allergies
  • Topical Nasal Steroids may reduce adenoid size and improve related symptoms.

Surgical Intervention: (Adenoidectomy)
  • Traditional Methods: Blind curettage adenoidectomy remains common, but it has disadvantages, including unpredictable bleeding and poor access to the choanal adenoid. Hence, Endoscopic management is currently preferred.
  • Direct Vision Techniques:
    • Suction Diathermy
    • Endoscopic Coblation/Microdebridement involves using endoscopy to visualise and allows for precise removal of obstructive adenoid tissue, addressing the underlying issue directly.
    • KTP Laser: Associated with a higher risk of nasopharyngeal stenosis, while the gold laser has not shown this risk.

Incorrect Options:

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion (Option B): would be the answer if the patient had serous otitis media with failed medical therapy (steroid nasal spray).

Antibiotic therapy (Option C): is usually preferred in an acute tonsillitis case.

Watchful waiting (Option D): Since the patient is symptomatic watchful waiting is not appropriate.

questions.text: What is the most commonly used test for newborn hearing screening?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Otoacoustic emissions (OAE)

Explanation:

  • OAE is the best and most commonly used test for newborn hearing screening.
  • Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is used to confirm hearing loss in infants and only in neonates who have failed OAE.
  • Uses of OAE:
    • They are used as a screening test for neonates, uncooperative or mentally challenged individuals.
    • Differentiate between cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss.
    • Helpful in early detection of noise-induced hearing loss.

Incorrect Options:


Options B, C & D: Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA), Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA), and Tympanometry are not the most commonly used tests for newborn hearing screening.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female working as a senior executive leading a sedentary lifestyle presents to the OPD with palmoplantar pigmentation. X-ray spine shows calcification of intervertebral discs. On adding Benedict’s reagent to the urine sample, it gives a greenish-brown precipitate and comes positive. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Homogentisic acid oxidase

Explanation

  • The patient is most likely suffering from alkaptonuria, a condition caused by homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency.
  • This leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid, which is excreted in the urine.
  • When exposed to air, the urine darkens, and a positive Benedict’s test (which detects reducing sugars) can produce a greenish-brown precipitate.
  • The palmoplantar pigmentation and intervertebral disc calcification (also known as ochronosis) are characteristic of this condition.

 

Alkaptonuria

Definition

Rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of homogentisate 1,2 dioxygenase (HGD), an enzyme in the tyrosine metabolism pathway.

Mechanism and Pathophysiology

Defective tyrosine metabolism → homogentisic acid (HGA) accumulation → ochronotic pigment deposition → systemic disease (ochronosis).

 

  • Deficiency: HGD fails to convert HGA to maleylacetoacetate.
  • Consequences:
    • HGA oxidizes into melanin-like polymers → connective tissue deposition (ochronosis).
    • Affects joints, heart valves, kidneys, and vessels.

Clinical Features
  • Triad: Homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, ochronotic osteoarthropathy.
  • Pediatric signs: Dark urine (oxidized HGA).
  • Musculoskeletal: Arthritis (spine, hips, knees), kyphoscoliosis, spinal stenosis.
  • Cardiac: Aortic stenosis, mitral valve disease, coronary artery disease.
  • Renal/Metabolic: Stones (renal, gallbladder, prostate).
  • Neurological: Peripheral neuropathy, stroke.

Evaluation
  • Clinical scoring: AKU Severity Score Index (AKUSSI).
  • Diagnostic tests:
    • Gold standard: Urinary HGA quantification via gas chromatography-mass spectrometry.
    • Genetic testing for HGD mutations.
    • Imaging (CT/MRI): Joint involvement, valvular calcification.
    • Echocardiography: Valvular abnormalities.

Management
  • Symptomatic: Pain control, physiotherapy, joint surgery.
  • Diet: Low-protein diet (limited efficacy).
  • Medications:
    • Vitamin C: Reduces HGA oxidation but not urinary excretion.
    • Nitisinone: Inhibits tyrosine metabolism, reduces HGA >95%. Side effects: tyrosinemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia.

Prognosis and Complications
  • Prognosis: Normal life expectancy; reduced quality of life (pain, sleep issues, disability).
  • Complications:
    • Stones (renal, gallbladder, salivary).
    • Tendon/ligament ruptures.
    • Osteopenia, fractures.
    • Aortic calcification/stenosis.

 

Phenylalanine hydroxylase (Option A): Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency causes phenylketonuria (PKU), which is associated with intellectual disability, seizures, and a musty odor. The symptoms described here are not typical of PKU.

Tyrosine hydroxylase (Option B): Tyrosine hydroxylase deficiency is associated with a condition called hereditary tyrosinemia type 2, which can cause eye and skin problems but does not present with the urine color change or intervertebral disc calcification seen in this case.

PHPP dioxygenase (Option D): Deficiency in 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase causes type III tyrosinemia, which is associated with elevated levels of tyrosine in the blood and urine, but does not typically present with palmoplantar pigmentation or calcification of intervertebral discs.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot on the retina?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tay-Sachs disease

Explanation

  • Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, developmental delay, and a cherry-red spot on the retina.

 

Tay-Sachs Disease

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Cause

Deficiency of hexosaminidase A enzyme

Accumulation

GM2 ganglioside in ganglion cells and neurons

Clinical Manifestations
  • Initial symptoms include loss of head control, inability to sit, exaggerated startle response to sound, and a disproportionately large head.
  • Progressive features include spasticity, deafness, and blindness.
  • Not associated with organomegaly.

Fundus Finding

Cherry-red spot is caused by GM2 ganglioside accumulation in the ganglion cells of the retina, creating a contrast with the normal red fovea.

 

Fabry's disease (Option B): Fabry's disease is caused by a deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A, leading to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. It presents with angiokeratomas, neuropathic pain, and renal involvement but does not typically feature a cherry-red spot on the retina.

Gaucher's disease (Option C): Gaucher's disease is due to glucocerebrosidase deficiency, causing glucocerebroside accumulation in macrophages. It presents with hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and cytopenias but is not associated with a cherry-red spot.

Von Gierke's disease (Option D): Von Gierke's disease (glycogen storage disease type I) results from a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase. It causes severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and lactic acidosis but does not involve retinal findings.

questions.text: Identify the most common location of Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) 2

Explanation:

  • The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal cancer is the Fossa of Rosenmuller.
  • The area marked as number 2 indicates the Fossa of Rosenmuller.

Aspect

Details

Definition

• A deep recess located in the nasopharynx, behind the torus tubarius (the cartilaginous opening of the Eustachian tube)

Location

• Posterolateral wall of the nasopharynx

• Just behind the Eustachian tube opening

Clinical Importance

• Common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) origin

• Close to the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube, so tumors here may cause ear symptoms

Related Structures

• Close to the Eustachian tube, tensor and levator veli palatini muscles, and retropharyngeal lymph nodes

Symptoms if Involved

• Unilateral ear blockage or hearing loss (due to Eustachian tube obstruction)

• Nasal obstruction, epistaxis (nosebleeds)

• Neck mass (from lymph node spread)

Incorrect Options:

Options A) Involvement of the superior nasopharynx (1) is uncommon but may lead to early skull base invasion and cranial nerve involvement.

Option C) Posterior nasopharynx (3): This site is less frequently affected compared to the lateral walls but may be involved in advanced cases.

Option D) This location is rare, but tumors here may cause early nasal symptoms such as epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and sinus involvement

questions.text: What is the preferred initial management for a patient presenting with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea?

choices.text: Bed rest with head elevation and avoidance of straining activities
Immediate surgical repair without initial medical management

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Bed rest with head elevation and avoidance of straining activities

Explanation:

  • The initial management for CSF Rhinorrhea is bed rest with head elevation and avoidance of straining activities.
  • It also includes administration of antibiotics and diuretics.

Treatment of CSF Rhinorrhea

  • Conservative Management:
    • Bed rest, head elevation
    • Stool softeners, avoidance of nose blowing, sneezing, and straining.
    • Prophylactic antibiotics to prevent meningitis
    • Acetazolamide to decrease CSF formation
    • Lumbar drain if indicated
  • Surgical Repair Approaches:
  1. Neurosurgical Intracranial Approach
  2. Extradural Approaches (rarely used):
  • External ethmoidectomy (cribriform plate/ethmoid area)
  • Transseptal sphenoidal approach
  • Osteoplastic flap (frontal sinus leaks)
  1. Transnasal Endoscopic Approach (preferred for anterior cranial fossa and sphenoid sinus):
  • Site identification (e.g., cribriform plate, sphenoid, ethmoid roof)
  • Grafting with fascia, and cartilage for large defects (>2 cm), followed by mucosa placement
  • Use of Surgicel and Gelfoam to further strengthen the area.
  • High-antibiotic nasal packing
  • Lumbar drain for high CSF pressure
  1. Frontal Sinus Leaks:
  • May require osteoplastic flap and sinus obliteration with fat.

Incorrect Options:

FESS (Option A): FESS is not used in the initial management for a patient with CSF Rhinorrhoea.

Administration of steroids (Option B): Administration of steroids is not preferred in the management of CSF Rhinorrhoea.

Immediate surgical repair without initial medical management (Option D): Immediate surgical repair without initial medical management is not preferred in management of CSF Rhinorrhea.

questions.text: Which structure is most commonly involved in the compression of the anterior ethmoid nerve, leading to Sluder's neuralgia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Middle turbinate

Explanation:

  • Middle turbinate, more than the inferior turbinate, is the most commonly involved structure in the compression of the anterior ethmoid nerve leading to anterior ethmoid neuralgia (Sluder's neuralgia).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C & D: Superior turbinate, inferior turbinate, and nasal septum are not the most commonly involved structures in the compression of anterior ethmoid nerve

questions.text: Which of the following topical local anesthetics is commonly used in cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Propracaine 0.5%

Explanation:

  • Proparacaine 0.5% is the most frequently used topical local anesthetic for cataract surgery due to its effectiveness in providing adequate anesthesia with minimal systemic effects.
  • It is preferred for its rapid onset and relatively short duration of action, which is well-suited for the brief nature of cataract procedures.

Incorrect Options:

Bupivacaine (Option B): Bupivacaine is more commonly used for spinal, epidural, and peripheral nerve blocks.

Halothane and Nitrous (Oxide Option C and D) are inhalational anesthetic agents used for general anesthesia, not topical local anesthesia.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a painful snakebite wound on his right foot. There are two fang marks with swelling and bleeding at the bite site. What is the first step in management?

choices.text: Sling or splint leading to immobilization
See the snake brought by a relative

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Sling or splint leading to immobilization

Explanation:

Initial management of snake bite involves the “RIGHT strategy.”

  • R: Reassure
  • I: Immobilize
  • G H: Go to the Hospital
  • T: Tell the appropriate history and symptoms to the attending doctor.
  • or coagulopathy, the recommended antivenom dose is 150-200 ml.

Management of Snakebite

Management

Details

Indications/Notes

First Aid
  • Do not allow the victim to walk (Carry)
  • Avoid tourniquets, except in specific cases(No)
  • Reassure patient
  • Immobilize bitten limb (Option B)
  • Transport to the hospital quickly
  • Tell the doctor about any systemic symptoms

Tourniquets only for severe elapid/sea snake bites with >0.5h but <2-3h transport time

Evaluation
  • Check for signs of envenomation
  • Monitor vital signs
  • Perform 20-minute whole blood clotting time
  • Check coagulation profile, CPK, renal function

Incoagulable blood indicates systemic envenomation by Viperidae

Antivenom Therapy
  • Mild: 50 ml
  • Moderate: 50-100 ml
  • Severe: 150-200 ml

Effective against the 4 most important venomous snakes in India, namely, Cobra, Common Krait, Russell's viper and saw-scaled viper.

Indications:

  • Haemostatic abnormalities
  • Neurotoxicity
  • Cardiovascular dysfunction
  • Impaired consciousness
  • Rhabdomyolysis
  • Extensive local swelling

Antivenom Administration (Option A)
  • Dilute in 5 ml/kg body weight of isotonic saline/5% Dextrose
  • Infuse over 1-2 hours
  • Monitor for hypersensitivity reactions

Repeat if severe signs persist after 1-2 hours or if coagulability is not restored within 6 hours

Supportive Care
  • Tetanus prophylaxis
  • Antibiotics (if severe local reaction)
  • Manage respiratory paralysis
  • Fresh frozen plasma/cryoprecipitates for severe bleeding

Avoid heparin, corticosteroids, and EDTA.

Venom suction (Option C) is to be avoided in case of a snake bite.

See the snake brought by a relative (Option D) This is not necessary as the ASV available is effective against all the common venomous snakes in India. Hence, ASV is administered regardless of the snake that caused the bite.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common drug used in day care surgery/TIVA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Propofol

  • Propofol is the preferred choice for daycare surgery and Total Intravenous Anesthesia (TIVA) due to its rapid onset and quick recovery profile. Additionally, Propofol is associated with a lower incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)

Propofol

  • Appearance: Clear, white emulsion, available as a 1% aqueous preparation (10 mg/mL) for IV administration.

Composition of Propofol

  • Chemical structure: phenol ring with two isopropyl groups.
  • Solubility: not water-soluble; available as a 1% aqueous oil-in-water emulsion.
  • Emulsion ingredients: contains soybean oil, glycerol, and egg lecithin.
  • Storage requirements: this should be administered within 6 hours of opening due to the risk of bacterial contamination, and a strict sterile technique is required
  • 0.005% disodium edetate or 0.025% sodium metabisulfite helps slow bacterial growth.

Pharmacokinetics of Propofol

  • Administration Route: only available for intravenous use.
  • Onset of Action: rapid onset; effects typically observed for 2–8 minutes after administration.
  • Distribution: short initial distribution half-life leads to quick awakening.
  • Recovery: faster recovery compared to other anesthetics, minimal "hangover" effects.
  • Biotransformation: high clearance exceeding hepatic blood flow (possible extrahepatic metabolism); metabolism occurs in the liver, resulting in inactive metabolites.
  • Excretion: Primarily eliminated via urine; unaffected by end-stage kidney disease.

Clinical Uses

  • Induction of Anesthesia: Suitable for patients aged 3 years and older; can be used in younger children with IV access.
  • Maintenance of Anesthesia: For patients over 2 months old.
  • Sedation:
    • During monitored anesthesia for various procedures.
    • For intubated, mechanically ventilated ICU patients.

Off-Label Uses

  • Management of refractory status epilepticus in both children and adults.
  • Treatment of refractory postoperative nausea and vomiting.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D are less commonly chosen for daycare surgeries

questions.text: Which of the following is the use of the Mallampatti classification?

choices.text: To evaluate the risk of surgery
To evaluate the pros and cons of surgery
To evaluate the fitness of the patient

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Endotracheal Intubation

  • The Mallampati classification is primarily used to assess the difficulty of endotracheal intubation. It evaluates the visibility of anatomical structures in the oral cavity to predict the ease or difficulty of securing the airway.

Mallampati Airway Classification

Mallampati Classification:

(Mnemonic - PUSH - Pillars, Uvula, Soft palate, Hard palate)

  • Class I: Faucial pillars, uvula, soft palate, and hard palate are visualized.
  • Class II: The base of the uvula, soft palate, and hard palate are visualized.
  • Class III: Soft palate and hard palate are visualized.
  • Class IV: Hard palate only is visualized.
  • Class 0: Any part of the epiglottis is visible (easy laryngoscopy with difficult airway management)

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D: The Mallampati classification is not used to evaluate the overall risk associated with surgery and does not provide insights into the pros and cons of surgical procedures. It does not assess a patient's general fitness for surgery.

questions.text: Blood during autopsy is preserved in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) NaF

Explanation:

  • For toxic analysis, like in alcohol abuse, the ideal preservative for blood is sodium fluoride.

Various methods of preserving viscera:

  1. Saturated salt solution
  2. Formalin fixation
  3. Freezing
  4. Alcohol preservation
  5. Formaldehyde solution
  6. Formalin-alcohol solution
  7. Frozen section
  8. Liquid nitrogen

Specimens for Analysis

Specimen

Importance

Blood

Primary specimen; collect from femoral, iliac, or axillary veins to avoid contamination.

Preservative: Lithium heparin or EDTA tube, Sodium fluoride/oxalate (Option A), if alcohol is suspected

Urine

Useful for detecting parent compounds and metabolites of poisons.

Preservative: No preservative, sodium fluoride is added, if alcohol is

Suspected

Gastric Contents

Helps identify ingested poisons and their concentrations through vomitus and stomach contents analysis.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison.(Option B)

Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid (Option C)

.

Liver

Analyzes metabolism and concentration of drugs; critical when blood/urine concentrations are low. Bile can detect specific substances like chlorpromazine and morphine.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison.

Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid.

Hair and Nails

Detects heavy metal poisoning; metals accumulate in keratin. Neutron activation analysis identifies specific metals and exposure patterns.

Scene Residues

Provides clues about the poison through materials found at the scene, such as tablets or empty containers.

Formalin (Option C) is commonly used for general tissue preservation and fixation in anatomical pathology, but it is not specifically preferred for toxicology autopsy. It may affect the results of toxicological analyses.

questions.text: A patient with a history of trauma presents with hearing loss. A High-Resolution Computed Tomography (HRCT) scan was performed. Which of the following structures is not typically visualized on HRCT?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Organ of Corti

Explanation:

  • HRCT of temporal bone is a specialized imaging technique used to obtain detailed images of the bones and air-filled spaces within the ear.
  • The organ of Corti is a neurosensory epithelium responsible for hearing present on the basilar membrane in scala media and it is difficult to identify it on HRCT.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & C: The cochlea, Vestibule, and Semicircular canals are bony structures and can be visualized on HRCT.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best drug to reduce LDL cholesterol levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Statins

Explanation:

  • Statins (e.g., atorvastatin and rosuvastatin) are the most effective class of drugs for lowering LDL cholesterol.
  • They work by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase, the enzyme responsible for cholesterol synthesis in the liver, leading to decreased cholesterol production and increased LDL receptor activity, thereby reducing LDL levels in the blood.
  • Most potent statin: Rosuvastatin
  • Most efficacious statin: Rosuvastatin > Atorvastatin
  • Longest-acting statin: Rosuvastatin > Atorvastatin
  • Safe in renal failure: Atorvastatin

Incorrect Options:

Niacin (Option A) is Vitamin B3 or nicotinic acid. It inhibits lipolysis in adipose tissue and ￬triglyceride production by the liver. It also ￪HDL levels.

Fibrates (Option B) activate peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α) and reduce triglyceride production, elevate HDL cholesterol levels and decrease hepatic triglyceride synthesis.

Resins (Option D) are drugs that include cholestyramine, colestipol, and colesevelam. They are used in adjunct with statin therapy, and they are safe to use in pregnancy.

questions.text: During measurement of a rifled barrel weapon, the caliber depends on?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Distance between two opposite lands

Explanation:

  • In forensic ballistics, "caliber" refers to the diameter of a rifled firearm's barrel, specifically measured between opposing lands. This measurement, typically expressed in inches or millimetres, is crucial for linking a bullet to a specific firearm.

Rifled Firearms:

  • Rifled firearms have a bore characterised by a series of grooves that spiral along the barrel's length. These grooves (Option B), known as "rifling," alternate with raised areas called "lands." The caliber is determined by measuring the distance between these lands. (Option A)
  • The direction of rifling can be either right (clockwise) or left (counter-clockwise), with most handguns featuring a right-hand twist.
  • As the bullet travels through the barrel, it engages with the lands and grooves, imparting a spin that stabilises its flight and leaves distinctive markings on the bullet, which serve as identifiers for the firearm.

Number of lead pellets (Option C)

  • Bore or Gauge: It is used for smooth bore weapons. The number of balls/pellets of equal size/weight made from 1 pound lead (454g) 12 bore = 12 balls

Mass and velocity (Option D) of a projectile fired from a rifled barrel weapon are important factors in its performance, they are not used directly to determine the caliber of the weapon

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with a history of hyperlipidemia was started on statins for elevated triglyceride levels. Despite the statin therapy, his triglycerides remain persistently elevated at over 600 mg/dL. Which of the following medications should be administered next to help manage the triglyceride levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fibrates

Explanation:

  • Fibrates (e.g., gemfibrozil and fenofibrate) are the most effective drugs for lowering triglycerides.
  • MOA: Activates PPAR-α ➜ ￪expression of genes involved responsible for triglycerides breakdown and VLDL clearance.
  • Fibrates can ￬triglycerides and ￪HDL cholesterol levels.

Incorrect Options:

Niacin (Option B) is Vitamin B3 or nicotinic acid. It inhibits lipolysis in adipose tissue and can lower triglycerides and increase HDL cholesterol, but it is less effective than fibrates for triglyceride lowering.

Statins (Option C) are primarily used to lower LDL cholesterol, but they have a modest effect on triglycerides. Since this patient’s triglycerides are still elevated despite statin therapy, adding a fibrate would be more appropriate.

Resins (Option D) are drugs that include cholestyramine, colestipol, and colesevelam. They are used in adjunct with statin therapy, and they are safe to use in pregnancy.

questions.text: During the forensic examination of semen from a rape victim, the identification of distinctive yellow needle-like crystals raises attention. What is the specific test employed to ascertain the presence of sperm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Barberio test

Explanation:

Barberio test, indicated by the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals, is used to identify the seminal fluid in this condition.

  • The Barberio test specifically detects Spermine, a compound derived from the prostate, and is used to identify seminal fluid.

 

Test Name

Substance Detected

Result

Reagent Used

Mnemonic

Notes

Barberio Test

Spermine

Yellow needle-shaped crystals of Spermine Picrate

Picric acid

Barbar picks your hair with a needle

Detects Spermine from the prostate; confirms the presence of seminal fluid.

Florence Test

Choline

Dark brown rhombic crystals of Choline iodide
