KI (Potassium Iodide)

Florence has 'C', C for Choline

It detects choline from the seminal vesicle and is used to identify seminal fluid.

 

Florence Test (Option D): This test detects choline and produces different crystal formations (dark brown rhombic crystals).

Acid phosphatase test (Option B) can be used to detect seminal fluid, as acid phosphatase is present in high concentrations in semen. The test does not involve the formation of yellow needle-like crystals.

Papanicolaou smear (Option C) commonly known as a Pap smear, is a screening test used to detect cervical cancer and abnormalities in cervical cells.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female who had a history of chronic sun exposure presented to the OPD clinic with brownish pigmentation as shown in the image. Which of the following is the diagnosis?

'
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Melasma

Explanation:

This woman with hyperpigmented patches on her cheek and a history of chronic sun exposure most likely has melasma.

Melasma:

  • It is characterized by hyperpigmented macules with scalloped or irregular margins that are darker than the surrounding areas.
  • These patches typically appear on the face, with common locations being the cheeks, forehead, and chin.
  • It is more common in females.
  • Etiologic factors include:
    • Genetic influences, ultraviolet (UV) radiation, pregnancy, hormonal therapies (Ex-OCPs), cosmetics, and phototoxic drugs.
  • Sun protection with broad-spectrum sunscreen with a high SPF, wearing protective clothing, and avoiding prolonged sun exposure aim to prevent further pigmentation.
  • Topical hydroquinone inhibits tyrosinase, an enzyme responsible for pigment production in melanocytes, and is a common depigmenting agent.
    • Triple combination therapy of hydroquinone, retinoid, and corticosteroid is highly effective for melasma.
    • Chemical peels, azelaic acid, and laser therapy are other options.

Freckles (Option B): Freckles (ephelides) are small, light-brown macules that darken with sun exposure and fade in winter. They are more common in fair-skinned individuals and appear in childhood.

Melanoma (Option C): Melanoma presents as an irregularly shaped, rapidly growing pigmented lesion with asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation, and possible ulceration. It does not typically present as uniform brown pigmentation.

Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) (Option D): BCC commonly appears as a pearly, translucent nodule with telangiectasia, central ulceration, or rolled borders, rather than diffuse pigmentation.

questions.text: During a police investigation, some bones are uncovered from the crime scene. Which of the following tests would aid in differentiating between human and canine bones, during the forensic analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Precipitin test

Explanation:

  • The test which can give the species differentiation is the precipitin test.
  • Precipitin tests can be done by extracting species-specific protein from bone into a solution and testing it against specific antisera of humans.
  • The techniques such as electrophoresis or gel diffusion can now identify human tissue.

Confirmatory Tests for Blood Stains in Forensic Medicine

  • Confirmatory tests are critical for identifying blood presence and origin in forensic investigations.
  • Methods include chemical, immunological, and mass spectrometry techniques for reliable results.

Chemical Confirmatory Tests

Test

Description

Takayama Test

Detects hemoglobin by forming red, feathery crystals of pyridine ferroprotoporphyrin.

Teichmann Test (Option D ruled out)

Converts hemoglobin to hemin, creating brownish-yellow rhomboid crystals, confirming blood presence.

Immunological Tests

Test

Description

Precipitin Test (Option A)

Identifies species origin through antibody-antigen reactions, using antisera specific to human blood.

HemaTrace Test

Uses monoclonal antibodies to detect human hemoglobin, showing a visible pink band for confirmation.

Mass Spectrometry Techniques

  • Thread Spray Mass Spectrometry: Analyzes whole blood directly on textiles, differentiating species based on lipid composition and hemoglobin chains. It offers high sensitivity and specificity.

Acid-phosphatase (Option B) This test can be used to detect seminal fluid.

LDH (Option C) cannot be used for species differentiation.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of recurrent lesions on lips as shown below, which is associated with fever. Which of the following is the characteristic feature seen in Tzanck smear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Multinucleated giant cells

Explanation:

  • The image given in the question is of Herpes labialis which is caused by Herpes simplex virus.
  • Fever is one of the predisposing factor of Herpes labialis
  • It is also called cold sore.
  • It is usually present on the vermillion border of the lips.
  • Smear is taken from the base of the vesicle
  • Multinucleated giant cells and Acantholytic cells are present on Tzanck smear

Herpes labialis/cold sore:

  • Reactivation of latent infection in trigeminal ganglion, causing asymptomatic shedding or clinically evident recurrent disease.
  • Causative organism: HSV-1 > HSV-2.
  • Features:
  • Painful and pruritic lesions.
  • Fever is often present, which subsides in 3-5 days. The initial vesicular lesions become pustular and then crusted before healing in 7-10 days without scarring.
  • Can be associated with itching or burning before the development of lesions.
  • Recurrent herpetic lesions are vesicular and ulcerative and tend to occur in the same region.
  • Treatment:

First line
  • Acyclovir (topical/oral)
  • Hydrocolloid dressing
  • Topical penciclovir

Second line
  • Long-term prophylactic acyclovir

Third line
  • IV acyclovir
  • Penciclovir
  • Foscarnet
  • IV cidofovir
  • Topical imiquimod

Handerson patterson bodies (Option A): Handerson patterson bodies is a histologic finding seen in Molluscum contagiosum.

Owl eye appearance (Option C): refers to basophilic intranuclear inclusions surrounded by a clear halo, characteristic of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

Acanthosis (Option D): Acanthosis is a histopathological finding seen in Chronic eczema.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for a patient presenting with diarrhea and a flask-shaped ulcer on a colonoscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Metronidazole

Explanation:

  • Flask-shaped ulcers on colonoscopy are a hallmark of amebic dysentery caused by the protozoan Entamoeba histolytica, reflecting tissue necrosis from the invasive trophozoites in the colon.
  • The first-line treatment for amebic dysentery is Metronidazole. The standard regimen is 400 mg three times a day for a week.

Tissue Amebicidal Drugs

 

Metronidazole

 
  1. DOC for all forms of amebiasis
  2. Treats amebic colitis and liver abscess
  3. Penetrates well into body tissues and fluids, including vaginal secretions, seminal fluid, saliva, breast milk, and cerebrospinal fluid.
  1. Effective against Entamoeba histolytica trophozoites but less effective against cysts.
  2. Inhibits protein synthesis in Entamoeba
  3. Treats giardiasis, trichomoniasis, and anaerobic infections
  4. Used in combination therapy for H. pylori infection

Tinidazole

 

Amebic colitis and liver abscess

Also used to treat Trichomoniasis.

Ornidazole

Acute amoebic dysentery

 

Secnidazole

Emetine

Acute amoebic dysentery or amoebic liver abscess in patients not tolerating metronidazole
  • Directly acting amoebicide that kills trophozoites but has no effect on cysts.
  • Side effects include vomiting and cardiotoxicity.

Chloroquine

Amoebic liver abscess

Kills the liver stage of Entamoeba histolytica

Luminal Amebicidal Drugs

Drug

Uses

Additional points & S/E

Paromomycin

(DOC)

An Aminoglycoside

Luminal agent for amebiasis.

An alternative drug for Giardiasis, especially in the first trimester of pregnancy where metronidazole is C/I.

Diloxanide furoate

Mild intestinal amebiasis

Furoate is the active moiety that kills Entamoeba

Quiniodochlor

 

Rarely used due to dangerous side effects such as SMON (Subacute myelo-optico-neuropathy)

Iodoquinol

Contains iodine and can cause thyroid abnormalities and allergy

Incorrect Options:

Ciprofloxacin (Option B) is a fluoroquinolone used to treat bacterial infections, but it is not effective against Entamoeba histolytica and would not be suitable for treating amebic dysentery.

Vancomycin (Option C) is the treatment of choice for Clostridium difficile infection (often presenting with pseudomembranous colitis), not for amebic dysentery. It would not target Entamoeba histolytica.

Ampicillin (Option D) is a penicillin antibiotic that does not have activity against the Entamoeba histolytica parasite and is not appropriate for treating amebic dysentery.

questions.text: A truck driver reports multiple painful genital ulcers on his scrotum following unprotected sexual intercourse, accompanied by painful lymph nodes. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chancroid

Explanation:

The patient's presentation of multiple painful genital ulcers with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy is highly suggestive of chancroid, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Chancroid:

  • Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi manifests as multiple ulcers in the genital area, characterized by their non-indurated nature, undermined edges, greyish slough, and tendency to bleed on touch.
  • Individuals with chancroid may develop unilateral, painful lymphadenopathy.
  • The suppurative lymphadenopathy observed in chancroid is termed bubo.
  • Diagnosis
    • Gram staining reveals Gram-negative bacilli arranged in chains, often referred to as "railway tracks" or "school of fish" appearance.
    • Culturing specimens on Mueller Hinton Agar supplemented with chocolate horse blood aids in the identification of Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • Treatment.
    • Azithromycin is administered orally in a single dose of 1 gram
    • OR intramuscular injection of Ceftriaxone at a dosage of 250 mg (single dose)

 

 

 

Ulcer

Lymph Node

 

Syphilis - treponema Pallidum

(Option A)

Painless genital ulcer called a chancre

Non-tender and rubbery in consistency.

 

Donovanosis- Klebsiella granulomatis

(Option C)

Painless, beefy red ulcers known as granulomas

Pseudo-bubo (enlarged and tender but occurs due to inflammation and not infection)

Herpes Simplex

(Option D)

Grouped vesicles or shallow erosions

Multiple, enlarged and inflamed.

Lymphogranuloma Venerum

(Chlamydia)

Solitary and painless.
  • Swollen, inflamed, and fluctuant lymph nodes containing purulent material.
  • Palpable groove or furrow that may be felt in the inguinal region due to the enlargement and fusion of the inguinal lymph nodes. (Groove of Greenlat)

questions.text: A diabetic patient was on medication and forgot to take his meals before going to the gym. He fainted while exercising, and their blood sugar level was found to be 60 mg/dL. Which of the following antidiabetic drugs can cause hypoglycemia when used in monotherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sulfonylureas

Explanation:

  • Sulfonylureas are insulin secretagogues that stimulate the pancreas to release more insulin, which can lead to an increased risk of hypoglycemia, especially when used in monotherapy, particularly if the patient skips meals, exercises excessively, or has altered insulin sensitivity.

Sulfonylureas

Site of Action

Pancreatic β cells

Uses

Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus

Mechanism of Action

Sulfonylureas ⟶ Bind to Receptors on Pancreatic β Cells ⟶ Closure of ATP-sensitive K+ Channels ⟶ Membrane depolarization ⟶ Opening of Voltage-Gated Ca².+ Channels ⟶ Ca²+ Influx ⟶ Exocytosis of Insulin Granules ⟶ Increased Insulin Secretion ⟶ Lower Blood Glucose Levels.

Drugs

1st Generation

  • Tolbutamide
  • Chlorpropamide

2nd Generation

  • Glibenclamide
  • Glipizide
  • Gliclazide
  • Glimepiride

Incorrect Options:

Metformin (Option B) primarily decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues. It does not stimulate insulin release from pancreatic beta cells. Hypoglycemia is unlikely with metformin unless it is combined with other medications like sulfonylureas or insulin.

Acarbose (Option C) is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that works by slowing down the digestion and absorption of carbohydrates in the small intestine. It does not cause hypoglycemia on its own and is not associated with hypoglycemic events.

Pioglitazone (Option D) is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity by acting as an agonist for the(PPAR-γ). This results in increased glucose uptake in muscle and adipose tissue and decreased glucose production in the liver. It does not cause hypoglycemia when used alone.

questions.text: Two handkerchiefs with blood stains are found at a crime scene. What is the most appropriate procedure for handling these items?

choices.text: Place them in same plastic bag and seal it for preservation
Rinse the bloodstains with water to prevent contamination
Place them in different plastic bags and seal it for preservation

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Preserve in an envelope/ paper bag

Explanation:

  • Paper bags or envelopes allow air to circulate, which helps prevent the growth of mold or bacteria on the blood stains.
  • Items stored in envelopes or paper bags can be easily labeled and documented, ensuring proper chain of custody and traceability of the evidence.

Incorrect Options:

Place them in the same plastic bag and seal it for preservation (Option A) risks cross-contamination between the two handkerchiefs, which can compromise the integrity of the evidence.

Rinse the bloodstains with water to prevent contamination (Option B) can alter the evidence and potentially wash away important forensic information.

Place them in different plastic bags and seal them for preservation (Option D) is not preferred as it can contain moisture and cause contamination.

questions.text: A child with a sore throat starts developing skin lesions as in the image below. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Guttate psoriasis

Explanation:

  • The image given above is of Guttate psoriasis
  • It is commonly seen in children.
  • It is usually preceded by streptococcal infection
  • Small, erythematous, scaly plaques on the trunk which gives raindrop-like appearance are seen
  • Treatment: Antibiotics (penicillin, amoxicillin)

Pustular Psoriasis (Option B): Pustular psoriasis (a type of unstable psoriasis) characterized by the presence of multiple sterile, non-infectious pus-filled blisters on erythematous skin, forming a characteristic 'Lakes of pus' appearance.

Erythrodermic Psoriasis (Option C): It is another variant of unstable psoriasis that presents with erythema and scales covering more than 90% of the body surface.

Inverse Psoriasis (Option D): Affects intertriginous areas (axilla, groin, inframammary folds) and presents with shiny, erythematous plaques without scaling, unlike guttate psoriasis.

questions.text: A patient underwent gastrointestinal surgery and had her jejunum resected. Which of the following drugs should be added to her treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Teduglutide

Explanation:

  • Teduglutide is a GLP-2 analogue that causes the growth of intestinal cells. It increases the absorptive power of the intestine and is approved for short-bowel syndrome treatment.
  • It reduces the need for parenteral nutrition in patients with short bowel syndrome.

Teduglutide

Type

Peptide hormone (GLP-2 analogue )

Mechanism of Action

Teduglutide ⟶ Binds to GLP-2 Receptors on Intestinal epithelial cells ⟶ Activation of Guanylate Cyclase ⟶ Increased production of cGMP ⟶ Activation of Protein Kinase G⟶ Regulation of Tight Junctions and Epithelial transporters ⟶ Enhanced intestinal absorption of fluid and nutrients ⟶ Improved glycemic control.

Uses

Treatment of short bowel syndrome (SBS) in adult patients who are dependent on parenteral support.

Benefits
  • Reduces dependence on parenteral nutrition
  • Improves intestinal absorption and transit time
  • Increases nutrient absorption and fluid balance

Side Effects
  • Nausea and Vomiting
  • Headache
  • Upper respiratory tract infection

Contraindications
  • Gastrointestinal obstruction or perforation
  • Gastrointestinal cancer

Special Points
  • Requires subcutaneous injection
  • Dosing and adjustment should be based on individual patient responses.
  • Regular monitoring of nutritional status and fluid balance is essential.

Incorrect Options:

Liraglutide (Option A) is a GLP-1 agonist primarily used for the treatment of type 2 diabetes and obesity. While it stimulates insulin release and slows gastric emptying, it does not have a specific role in managing short bowel syndrome.

Exenatide (Option C) is another GLP-1 agonist used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. Like liraglutide, it primarily works by enhancing insulin secretion and delaying gastric emptying but does not directly address the needs of a patient with short bowel syndrome.

Semaglutide (Option D) is also a GLP-1 agonist, similar to liraglutide and exenatide. While it is effective for diabetes and weight loss, it does not address the specific needs of short bowel syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures has been banned by the Supreme Court of India due to its association with sexual assault cases involving doctors?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Two-finger test

Explanation:

  • The two-finger test is banned by the Supreme Court of India because it infringes on the privacy, physical and mental integrity, and dignity of rape survivors.

BNSS Section 184 - Medical examination of Victim of Rape

Step

Details

Request for Examination
  • Any police officer can request it within 24 hours.

Consent
  • Must obtain consent from the woman
  • Examination supervised by a female RMP.

Initial Examination
  • Ask the victim to remove clothing.
  • Examine and collect evidence from clothes.
  • Look for foreign objects (hairs, seminal stains)
  • Search for physical injuries.

Detection of Micro Injuries
  • Apply toluidine-blue contrast to the anogenital area.

Swabs Collection
  • 4 swabs:
    • Smear: Prepare a smear for microscopic examination.
    • Sperm: Use saline for motility testing.
    • DNA Profiling
    • Chemical Tests: Acid phosphatase, creatinine phosphokinase, lactate dehydrogenase.

Examination Position
  • Examine in lithotomy position under good lighting.

Hymen Examination
  • Use Glaister-Keene rods or hymenoscope
  • Look for tears (usually posterior at 5-7 o'clock position).

Vaginal Examination
  • Use a speculum for vaginal examination.(Option C)

Cervical Examination
  • Use a colposcope for cervical examination. (Option B)

Post-Examination Care
  • Treat STDs, injuries, or potential pregnancy.
  • Provide psychological support.

Foley’s catheter (Option A) is used for treatment purpose and can be used in rape victims

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of Local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Blocks Na+ channels

Explanation:

  • Local anesthetics work by blocking sodium channels in nerve membranes, preventing the propagation of nerve impulses, which results in local anesthesia.
  • MOA: Blocks inactivation gates of Na+ channels → Disrupts depolarisation → No action potential generated → No pain sensation.

Incorrect Options:

Stimulate Ca+ Channels (Option A): Calcium channels are involved in neurotransmitter release at synapses, but local anesthetics do not stimulate Ca²⁺ channels. They primarily block sodium channels.

Block Cl- Channels (Option B): Chloride channels play a role in the regulation of cell volume and maintaining membrane potential, but local anesthetics do not block chloride channels.

Stimulate K+ channels (Option C): Potassium channels are involved in the repolarization phase of the action potential, but local anesthetics do not directly stimulate these channels. Their primary effect is on sodium channels to block nerve conduction.

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism of action of methotrexate?

choices.text: Inhibits DNA synthesis by blocking thymidylate synthase
Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to decreased DNA synthesis
Inhibits RNA synthesis by blocking RNA polymerase
Interferes with microtubule formation during cell division

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to decreased DNA synthesis

Explanation:

  • Methotrexate is an antimetabolite and antifolate drug that primarily inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).
  • DHFR is responsible for converting dihydrofolate (DHF) into tetrahydrofolate (THF).
  • THF is essential for the synthesis of purine nucleotides and thymidylate, which are crucial for DNA synthesis and repair. (Option A)
  • By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate decreases the production of THF, leading to a reduction in DNA synthesis.

Inhibits RNA synthesis by blocking RNA polymerase (Option C): Methotrexate does not inhibit RNA polymerase directly. It primarily affects DNA synthesis by inhibiting DHFR.

Interferes with microtubule formation during cell division (Option D): This mechanism is associated with drugs like taxanes and vinca alkaloids, which disrupt microtubule dynamics and mitosis. Methotrexate does not work through this mechanism.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Ethosuximide?

choices.text: Inhibits calcium channels in thalamic neurons

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inhibits calcium channels in thalamic neurons

Explanation:

  • Ethosuximide blocks T-type calcium channels in the thalamus and prevents the firing of action potential to the cortex.
  • By inhibiting these channels, ethosuximide reduces neuronal excitability in the thalamus and helps prevent these abnormal brain wave patterns, thereby controlling the seizures.
  • It is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures.

Incorrect Options:

Enhances GABAergic inhibition (Option A): Drugs like benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam) and barbiturates enhance GABAergic inhibition by increasing GABA receptor activity. Ethosuximide does not primarily act on GABA receptors.

Blocks sodium channels (Option C): Sodium channel blockers (e.g., phenytoin, carbamazepine) are effective for other types of seizures, but ethosuximide does not primarily work by blocking sodium channels.

Increases serotonin levels (Option D): Some antidepressants and antipsychotics modulate serotonin levels, but ethosuximide's mechanism of action is not related to increasing serotonin.

questions.text: A female patient with a history of bronchial asthma has developed an acute attack of migraine. Which drug should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Propranolol

Explanation:

  • Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that blocks both beta-1 (found in the heart) and beta-2 receptors (found in the bronchial smooth muscle).
  • Blocking beta-2 receptors can lead to bronchoconstriction, which can exacerbate symptoms in patients with bronchial asthma or lead to severe bronchospasm.
  • Propranolol is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to its potential to worsen asthma symptoms, making it a poor choice in this scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Sumatriptan (Option A) is a 5HT1B/1D receptor agonist. It is used in patients who fail to respond to analgesics. It can cause coronary vasoconstriction, but it does not cause significant bronchoconstriction and is generally safe for use in asthma patients.

Ergotamine (Option C) is an ergot alkaloid that is used to treat migraines by causing vasoconstriction. It does not directly cause bronchoconstriction like propranolol.

Lasmiditan (Option D) is a 5-HT1F receptor agonist used as an alternative to triptans, especially for those with cardiovascular diseases, and it is not contraindicated for asthma.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with generalized muscle weakness and protrusion of the eyelids (ptosis) that worsens as the day progresses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Myasthenia Gravis

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Myasthenia Gravis (MG), an autoimmune disorder affecting the neuromuscular junction.

Clinical Features of Myasthenia Gravis:

  • Fatigable muscle weakness: Muscle strength decreases with continued use, especially:
    • Later in the day as day progresses
    • After exercise
  • No sensory or CNS involvement, distinguishing it from other neurological disorders.

Common Initial Symptoms

  • Ptosis (drooping eyelid)
  • Diplopia (double vision)
  • Weakness can spread to:
    • Chewing, swallowing, and speaking muscles
    • Limb muscles

Muscle Weakness Patterns:

Affected Muscles

Key Features

Ocular muscles

Mimics central eye movement disorders.

Cogan's lid twitch sign

Upper eyelid rises briefly after looking down for some time.

Shoulder girdle muscles

Difficulty in overhead activities like combing hair.

Respiratory muscles

Weakness may cause respiratory failure and aspiration risks.

 

Fibromyalgia (Option B): This chronic condition is characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points rather than true muscle weakness. It does not present with ptosis or demonstrate diurnal variation in symptoms.

Myotonic Dystrophy (Option C): This genetic disorder causes progressive muscle weakness with myotonia (delayed muscle relaxation) and primarily affects distal muscles. The absence of myotonia and presence of generalized muscular weakness points away from this diagnosis.

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (Option D): Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), the acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, cardinally presents with acute-onset symmetric flaccid limb weakness. This acute ascending paralysis typically begins in the lower extremities and progresses upward.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for detecting enteric fever in the first week?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Blood culture

Explanation:

  • Blood culture is the most sensitive diagnostic modality for early detection of enteric fever, as Salmonella typhi or Salmonella paratyphi are present in the bloodstream during the initial phase of infection.

Duration of Disease

Specimen Examination

% Positivity

1st week

Blood culture

90%

2nd week

Blood culture

Faeces culture

Widal test

75%

50%

Low Titre

3rd week

Widal test

Blood culture

Faeces culture

80-100%

60%

80%

4th week

Urine Culture

25-40%

Urine culture (Option B): This test becomes relevant only in the fourth week of illness when bacteria begin to be excreted in the urine. By this time, the disease has already progressed significantly, making it unsuitable for early diagnosis.

Stool culture (Option C): This investigation typically becomes positive in the third week of illness when bacteria are shed in the feces. It is not useful for early diagnosis as bacterial shedding in stool occurs later in the disease course.

Antibody detection (Option D): The Widal test for antibody detection is generally performed in the second week of illness, as antibodies take time to develop. The test has low sensitivity and specificity in the first week.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diagnostic test for carcinoid tumors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate that carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete serotonin, which is metabolized to 5-HIAA and excreted in urine.

Diagnosis of Carcinoid Syndrome

Diagnostic Method

Details

5-HIAA Urine Test
  • Primary diagnostic test
  • 24-hour urine collection
  • Measures serotonin metabolites
  • Can be challenging if patient is consuming serotonin-rich foods (e.g., salmon, eggs)

Somatostatin Scintigraphy
  • Also known as OctreoScan
  • Can confirm presence of somatostatin receptors
  • Helps in tumor localization
  • Used to predict response to somatostatin analogue therapy

68Ga-DOTATATE PET Scan
  • More sensitive imaging technique
  • Uses radioactive gallium-68
  • Helps predict response to treatment
  • Particularly useful for NET imaging

Chromogranin A
  • Blood test biomarker
  • Elevated in metastatic disease
  • Should be interpreted with caution in patients with renal dysfunction, patients taking PPIs
  • Not diagnostic alone, but helpful in monitoring

Clinical Symptoms
  • Flushing episodes (2-5 mins)
  • Diarrhea
  • Wheezing
  • Heart valve problems
  • Abdominal pain
  • Telangiectasia

24-hour urinary catecholamines (Option A): This test is used to diagnose pheochromocytoma and other catecholamine-secreting tumors, not carcinoid tumors. Catecholamines are not characteristic of carcinoid syndrome.

Serum calcitonin levels (Option B): This test is used to diagnose medullary thyroid carcinoma, which is a different type of neuroendocrine tumor. Calcitonin is unlikely to be elevated in carcinoid syndrome.

Serum chromogranin A (Option C): While chromogranin A can be elevated in some neuroendocrine tumors, it is not specific for carcinoid tumors and is not the diagnostic test of choice. It may be used as a supplementary marker but not for primary diagnosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a 20-year history of chronic alcohol consumption, averaging 500 ml daily, presents to the clinic with complaints of sensations of insects crawling on his skin, agitation, and irritation. He reports that his last drink was 3 days ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Delirium tremens

Explanation:

  • The patient’s agitation, hallucinations (insects crawling), and history of heavy alcohol use with cessation 3 days ago suggest delirium tremens that typically occur 48-72 hours after the last drink in individuals with chronic alcohol use.

Stage of Alcohol Withdrawal

Symptoms

Onset After Last Drink

Treatment

Mild Withdrawal

Mild anxiety, tremulousness, nausea, headache, palpitations

6-8 hours

Benzodiazepines (lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam). Carbamazepine (800 mg daily).

Moderate (Alcoholic Hallucinosis)

Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations, intact orientation, normal vital signs

8-12 hours

Benzodiazepines (lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).

Severe (Withdrawal Seizures)

Generalized tonic-clonic seizures, usually brief and self-limited (rum fits)

12-24 hours

Benzodiazepines (Treatment of choice).

Anticonvulsants not more beneficial.

Life-Threatening (Delirium Tremens)

Severe agitation, confusion, disorientation, visual hallucinations, autonomic hyperactivity, profound sweating, tremors, insomnia

Within 72 hours

Higher doses of Benzodiazepines (50-100 mg chlordiazepoxide every 4 hours or lorazepam IV). Supportive care (high-calorie diet, multivitamins).

Haloperidol for severe agitation (caution with seizure threshold).

Protracted Withdrawal

Symptoms may last 2-6 months

-

Acamprosate is recommended for symptom relief, and cognitive and behavioural approaches are recommended.


Incorrect Options:

Alcohol intoxication (Option A) can cause disorientation and behavioural changes, but it doesn't cause diplopia or insect crawling sensation on the skin. The excitement that follows drinking is due to CNS depression.

Tolerance (Option C): An Increased amount of substance is required to produce the desired effects previously produced by lower amounts. It develops quickly (2-3 days of repeated use), lost after 4-6 days of abstinence.

Reaction due to alcohol (Option D) is an immediate response following alcohol consumption.

questions.text: What is the medical term for a person who fears seeing tall buildings and looking down from heights?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acrophobia

Explanation:

  • Acrophobia is referred to as an intense fear of heights, often leading to anxiety and panic when in high places or even when thinking about being at a height.
  • The term "phobia" is used when fear is limited to a specific object, situation, or idea. Phobias are linked to physical symptoms of anxiety and a tendency to avoid the feared stimulus.

Incorrect Options:

Agoraphobia (Option A) is a fear of entering open or crowded places or being in places where escape might be difficult. Those affected often avoid crowded areas, public transport, or being far from home, and in severe cases, may avoid leaving home altogether.

Claustrophobia (Option C) is the intense fear of enclosed or small spaces. These individuals may experience anxiety, panic, and discomfort when in places like elevators, tunnels, or crowded rooms.

Nomophobia (Option D) is a fear or anxiety of being without a mobile phone or losing access to it. People often experience distress when they cannot use their phone due to factors like low battery, lack of signal, or being without it.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a history of lower back pain and painful urination. Upon investigation, he is found to have normocytic normochromic anemia and hypercalcemia. Serum protein electrophoresis reveals an M-spike in the gamma region. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bence Jones protein in urine

Explanation:

  • Clinical features of CRAB (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia, and bone lesions), along with the presence of an Gamma region M spike in serum electrophoresis, point towards the diagnosis of Multiple myeloma.

Investigations of Multiple myeloma:

  • Hematological Analysis:
    • It may reveal anemia; ESR is usually elevated.
    • Rare cases of plasma cell leukemia with high plasma cell counts >2000 plasma cells/μL.
    • Serum calcium and urea nitrogen may be elevated.
    • Serum alkaline phosphatase is usually normal.
    • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation
  • A/G ratio: Decreased
    • Increased level of β2 microglobulin.
    • Decreased albumin
  • Renal function test: Increased serum creatinine and uric acid.
  • Imaging:
    • Chest and bone radiographs: Lytic lesions/diffuse osteopenia
    • MRI: Extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome
    • PET/CT: Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease
  • Anion gap: (Na+ + K+) – (Cl- + HCO3-): Decreased
  • Serum or urine electrophoresis: M spike
  • Serum light chain assay: Increased
  • Immunofixation: Detects subtypes of light chain.
  • 24-hour urine specimen: Bence Jones protein (serum-free light chains) excretion
  • Fat pad biopsy: To detect amyloid deposits
  • Flow cytometry: CD 138+ (bone marrow plasma cells)
  • FISH:
    • Done to detect chromosomal abnormalities
    • Chromosome 17 deletion and translocation leads to poor prognosis.
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasmacytosis >10%

 

Liver function test (Option A): While liver function tests may be abnormal in some patients with multiple myeloma, they are not specific or diagnostic for the condition. LFTs are more useful in assessing liver involvement or complications.

Urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (Option C): This test assesses kidney function and proteinuria but is not specific for multiple myeloma. While renal function may be affected in myeloma, UACR doesn't detect the characteristic Bence Jones proteins.

Heat and acetic acid test (Option D): This is an outdated test that is not used in modern diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Current diagnostic methods are more sensitive and specific.

questions.text: A mother presented her daughter with complaints that she has started behaving weirdly about her food habits for the last few months. She eats a lot of burgers in one go, and then she vomits it out. Her BMI is 27. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bulimia nervosa

Explanation:

  • The patient exhibits binge eating followed by vomiting, which is characteristic of Bulimia nervosa (eating disorder).

Bulimia Nervosa (eating disorder)

Age of Onset

Late adolescence and young adulthood (8-21 years).

Features

  • Binge Eating Episodes: Recurring episodes of binge eating, occurring at least weekly for the last 3 months.
  • Compensatory Behaviors: Purging behaviours (self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics), excessive exercise, fasting.
  • BMI: Often normal or slightly overweight (compared to anorexia nervosa).
  • Gender prevalence: More common in females than males.

Physical signs

Appear due to repeated purging.

  • Parotitis or (parotid gland hypertrophy (may see increased serum amylase)
  • Enamel erosion (from vomiting)
  • Dental caries
  • Mallory-Weiss syndrome (esophageal tears).
  • Russell's Sign (callus on knuckles: Due to self-induced vomiting, the knuckles get injured by the teeth.

Treatment

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT):

  • First-line treatment focuses on modifying distorted thoughts and behaviours related to eating and body image.

Nutritional Rehabilitation:

  • Aimed at restoring healthy eating patterns and addressing nutritional deficiencies.

Antidepressants

  • Fluoxetine: Most effective medication for reducing binge-eating episodes and associated symptoms.
  • Topiramate: This can be effective in suppressing binge eating but not as commonly used as fluoxetine.
  • Bupropion: Contraindicated due to an increased risk of seizures, especially in patients with eating disorders.

Evidence indicates that CBT and medications (particularly fluoxetine) are the most effective combination.

Incorrect Options:

Anorexia nervosa (Option A) involves an intense fear of gaining weight and a distorted body image, as seen in the patient's anxiety over gaining a few pounds. It also includes behaviours like binge eating followed by purging, such as self-induced vomiting, but with a decreased BMI.

Binge eating disorder (Option B) does not involve purging behaviours and is characterised by episodes of eating large quantities of food without compensatory actions.

OCD (Obsessive Compulsive Disorder) (Option D) is not an eating disorder. It is characterised by persistent, unwanted thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviours (compulsions) performed to reduce anxiety. Individuals often feel compelled to engage in these actions despite recognising them as irrational.

questions.text: A young woman presents with recurrent headaches, easy bruising, and episodes of visual blurring. Her platelet count is elevated, while her red blood cell (RBC) and white blood cell (WBC) counts are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Essential Thrombocytosis

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Essential Thrombocytosis, a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by an isolated elevation in platelet count. The patient presents with classic symptoms including headaches, easy bruising, and visual disturbances, along with the key diagnostic finding of elevated platelets with normal RBC and WBC counts.
  • This condition results from abnormal proliferation of megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, leading to excessive platelet production.

 

Essential Thrombocytosis

Definition
  • Clonal myeloproliferative disorder
  • Characterized by increased platelet production
  • Abnormal megakaryocyte proliferation

Genetics
  • JAK2 V617F mutation (50-60% of cases)
  • CALR mutations (type 1 and 2)
  • MPL mutations

Lab Findings
  • Platelet count >450,000/μL
  • Increased bone marrow megakaryocytes
  • Normal RBC and WBC Count

Clinical Features
  • Often asymptomatic
  • Thrombotic events (arterial > venous)
  • Erythromelalgia
  • Ocular migraines & visual disturbances
  • TIAs
  • Spontaneous bleeding & easy bruising

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Platelet count >450,000/μL
  • Bone marrow showing megakaryocyte proliferation
  • Not meeting WHO criteria for other myeloid neoplasms
  • Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation

Complications
  • Thrombosis (major cause of morbidity)
  • Hemorrhage (especially with counts >1 million/μL)
  • Progression to myelofibrosis
  • Small risk of leukemic transformation

Treatment
  • Low-dose aspirin for thrombosis prevention
  • Hydroxyurea for high-risk patients
  • Anagrelide for cytoreduction
  • Plateletpheresis for severe cases

 

Polycythemia Vera (Option B) presents with elevated levels of all three blood cell lines—RBCs, WBCs, and platelets. The normal RBC count in this case makes this diagnosis unlikely. Patients typically present with ruddy complexion, pruritus, and thrombotic complications.

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (Option C) typically shows elevation in granulocytes and often an increase in platelets as well. The presence of normal WBC count makes CML an unlikely diagnosis, as it characteristically presents with marked leukocytosis.

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (Option D) typically presents with abnormal levels of blood cells and can show varying counts of WBCs, RBCs, and platelets. The normal blood counts except for platelets make AML less likely, as it usually presents with cytopenias and blast cells in the peripheral blood.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient who has been on anti-diabetic therapy for the last 10 years, has experienced three episodes of vaginal candidiasis infections in the past two months. Which hypoglycemic agent should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gliflozins

Explanation:

  • Gliflozins, also known as SGLT2 inhibitors, inhibit the sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 in the proximal renal tubules.
  • SGLT2 is a low-affinity, high-capacity sodium-glucose cotransporter that is responsible for reabsorbing approximately 90% of filtered glucose in the proximal tubule.
  • Gliflozins reduce glucose reabsorption and increase glucose excretion in the urine
  • .The presence of excess glucose in the urine creates an environment conducive to the growth of fungi, thereby increasing the risk of infections such as vaginal candidiasis.
  • It includes drugs that end with word - flozin :
    • Dapagliflozin,
    • Empagliflozin,
    • Canagliflozin,
    • Ertugliflozin.

Incorrect Options:

Acarbose (Option A) works by inhibiting enzymes that break down carbohydrates in the intestines, thus slowing glucose absorption and lowering postprandial blood sugar levels. It does not impact the urinary glucose concentration and is not associated with an increased risk of UTIs.

Metformin (Option B) is a biguanide and the most commonly used first-line medication for type 2 diabetes. It works by reducing liver glucose production and improving insulin sensitivity. It does not increase the risk of vaginal candidiasis.

Linagliptin (Option D) is a DPP-4 inhibitor that increases incretin hormones, which help to increase insulin release and decrease glucagon release. It does not typically cause infections like vaginal candidiasis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a unilateral throbbing headache that worsens with exposure to bright light. She occasionally skips breakfast. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Migraine

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate a migraine headache. According to Diagnostic Criteria for Migraine by International Headache Society, criteria includes features such as unilateral location, throbbing quality, and photophobia (sensitivity to bright light).
  • The condition is characterized by recurrent episodes that can be triggered by various factors, including missed meals, as noted in the patient's history of occasionally skipping breakfast. Migraines typically last between 4-72 hours and may be accompanied by nausea and other sensory sensitivities.

Clinical Features of Migraine

Premonitory (Prodromal) Phase
  • Neck discomfort
  • Cognitive impairment (brain “fog”)
  • Mood changes
  • Fatigue
  • Yawning/sleepiness
  • Increased urination and thirst
  • Food cravings

Aura
  • Neurologic disturbances (e.g., visual disturbances like scintillating scotoma)
  • Due to Cerebral vasoconstriction. Therefore prevention is by Vasodilators.

Headache Phase
  • Pain
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Sensory sensitivities:
    • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
    • Phonophobia (sensitivity to sound)
    • Osmophobia (sensitivity to smells)
    • Allodynia (pain from non-painful stimuli)
    • Vertigo
  • Due to cerebral vasodilation. So treatment is Vasoconstrictors

Postdrome
  • Tiredness
  • Weariness
  • Impaired concentration

Simplified Diagnostic Criteria for Migraine by International Headache Society:

Criteria:

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4–72h in patients with a normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for the headache, and:

 

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

 

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

 

Hunger headache (Option A) is typically bilateral rather than unilateral and does not present with photophobia or throbbing pain. These headaches are generally diffuse and associated with hypoglycemia due to missed meals, improving rapidly with food intake.

Tension headache (Option C) presents with bilateral, steady, pressing pain rather than unilateral throbbing pain. These headaches typically feel like a tight band around the head and are not characteristically aggravated by light or accompanied by photophobia.

Cluster headache (Option D) presents with severe, strictly unilateral pain centered around the eye, often accompanied by autonomic symptoms such as lacrimation and nasal congestion. These headaches occur in clusters lasting weeks to months, with multiple short-duration attacks per day, and typically do not have the strong association with photophobia seen in this case.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with obstructive lung disease is currently using salmeterol and tiotropium but continues to experience breathlessness and frequent exacerbations. Given her current situation, which of the following treatments would be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Long-Term Oxygen Therapy (LTOT)

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate persistent symptoms of obstructive lung disease despite optimal bronchodilator therapy with salmeterol (LABA) and tiotropium (LAMA).
  • Long-Term Oxygen Therapy (LTOT) is the most appropriate next step in management as it addresses potential hypoxemia, which is often present in patients with chronic obstructive lung disease experiencing persistent symptoms.
  • This therapy can improve survival and quality of life in patients who are already on bronchodilator therapy, by increasing oxygen levels in the blood and reducing the strain on the cardiopulmonary system.

Interventions for Improved Survival in COPD:

  • Smoking Cessation:
    • Most crucial intervention for improving survival.
    • Slows decline in lung function (FEV1), altering disease progression.
  • Long-Term Oxygen Therapy (LTOT):
    • Improves survival in severe hypoxaemia (PaO2 < 7.3 kPa).
    • Recommended use: at least 15 hours/day, with greater benefit at >20 hours/day.
  • Pulmonary Rehabilitation:
    • Improves symptoms, exercise tolerance, and health status.
    • May contribute to better survival, though direct link needs more research.
  • Management of Exacerbations:
    • Crucial for reducing mortality.
    • Key components:
      • Controlled oxygen therapy (24%-28%) to maintain PaO2 > 8 kPa.
      • Nebulised bronchodilators: salbutamol + ipratropium.
      • Oral glucocorticoids: prednisolone 30 mg for 10 days.
      • Antibiotics for increased sputum purulence/volume, breathlessness.
      • Non-invasive ventilation (NIV) for mild-moderate acidosis (pH < 7.35).
  • Vaccination:
    • Annual influenza and pneumococcal vaccinations to prevent infections and exacerbations.
    • Multidisciplinary Management:
    • Address comorbidities (e.g., obesity, malnutrition, depression, social isolation).
    • These factors impact overall health and survival.

Nebulization with LAMA-LABA (Option A) provides the same medications the patient is already taking in a different delivery form. Switching to nebulized form of the same medications is unlikely to provide significant additional benefit when the patient is already on optimal inhaler therapy.

Positive Pressure Ventilation (Option C) is typically reserved for acute respiratory failure or severe COPD exacerbations requiring intensive care management. It is not an appropriate choice for chronic outpatient management of stable COPD with persistent symptoms.

Pneumococcal Vaccine (Option D) is an important preventive measure for COPD patients to prevent infectious exacerbations. However, it would not address the immediate concern of persistent breathlessness and frequent exacerbations in a patient already on optimal bronchodilator therapy.

questions.text: A lumbar puncture was performed on a patient in a sitting position, and the patient is now experiencing a very severe headache. Which of the following is NOT a recommended management strategy for a post-lumbar puncture headache?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Restrict water intake

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate a post-lumbar puncture headache (PDPH). Restricting fluid intake is not a standard approach used in the management of PDPH
  • Postdural puncture headache (PDPH) is a potential complication of a lumbar puncture, with symptoms caused by traction on pain-sensitive structures from low cerebrospinal fluid pressure (intracranial hypotension) following a leak of cerebrospinal fluid at the puncture site. Traumatic needles like Quincke, Babcock and also needles with lower gauge can cause PDPH.
  • Definitive treatment with an epidural blood patch is recommended when symptoms persist even after conservative treatment.

 

Management of PDPH:

  • Bed rest for 8-12 hours
  • Analgesics
  • Intravenous caffeine
  • Despite symptomatic treatment, if the headache persists:
    • Low Volume Blood patch: For this procedure, 10 ml to 30 ml of autologous venous blood is injected by an anesthesiologist into the epidural space at the level of the prior procedure. This is thought to create a "patch" over the dural puncture and decrease CSF leak, or simply increase the intracranial pressure.

 

Lie in a supine position (Option A) is a recommended first-line management strategy for post-lumbar puncture headaches. The supine position helps reduce cerebrospinal movement and fluid leakage through gravity and allows the dura to seal.

Administer intravenous caffeine (Option B) is an appropriate intervention for post-lumbar puncture headaches. Caffeine acts as a vasoconstrictor, which can help reduce the headache by decreasing cerebral vessel dilation and improving cerebrospinal fluid production.

Perform a low-volume blood patch (Option D) is a definitive treatment option for persistent post-lumbar puncture headaches that don't respond to conservative measures. This procedure involves injecting autologous blood into the epidural space to seal the CSF leak and provide headache relief.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with colicky abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura. Urinalysis shows only red blood cells with no other significant findings. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) IgA vasculitis

Explanation:

The scenario of colicky abdominal pain, joint pain, palpable purpura, and hematuria without proteinuria suggests Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (IgA Vasculitis).

  • It is an IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis characterized by inflammation of small blood vessels.
  • The exact cause of HSP is unclear, but it is thought to involve an abnormal immune response, where IgA immune complexes deposit in blood vessel walls, causing inflammation and damage.
  • It is more common in children but can occur in adults.
  • It is characterized by
    • Henoch Schonlein purpura (palpable purpura)
    • Purpuric rash in lower limbs
    • Abdominal pain
    • Arthralgia
    • Renal (hematuria)
  • It is associated with elevated serum IgA levels.
  • Urinalysis: The presence of red blood cells cast in urine.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) (Option B), also known as Wegener's granulomatosis, is an autoimmune condition that primarily affects the small- to medium-sized blood vessels, leading to granulomatous inflammation and necrosis. It involves respiratory symptoms and renal issues, while Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP) is more likely here due to abdominal pain, joint pain, and palpable purpura, which are hallmark features of HSP with IgA deposition.

Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) (Option C) is a small-vessel vasculitis primarily affecting the kidneys and lungs, often presenting with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary symptoms like hemoptysis, along with ANCA positivity.


Behcet's disease (Option D) is a systemic vasculitis that presents with oral and genital ulcers, ocular involvement, and skin lesions like erythema nodosum.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with intermenstrual bleeding following the insertion of an intrauterine device (IUD). She reports no other complications. What is the most appropriate initial management step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Reassure the patient and observe

Explanation:

Intermenstrual bleeding is a common side effect following IUD insertion. It occurs due to the body's adjustment to the device and can persist for a few cycles. Management includes:

  • Reassurance and observation as the first-line approach
  • Tranexamic acid or NSAIDs can be used during the first few cycles to manage bleeding if needed

Remove the IUD (Option A): Removal is generally not necessary unless there are additional signs of complications such as severe pain, abnormal discharge, or evidence of infection.

Perform a pelvic ultrasound (Option C): While ultrasound might be considered if there are additional symptoms or concerns, it is not routinely needed solely for intermenstrual bleeding following IUD insertion.

Prescribe hormonal therapy (Option D): Hormonal therapy is not the first-line treatment for intermenstrual bleeding after IUD insertion. The primary approach is to observe and manage symptoms conservatively unless there are indications for further intervention.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient visits a haematologist with symptoms of weakness and fatigue. Laboratory tests show low haemoglobin, a low reticulocyte count, and normal WBC and platelet counts. The bone marrow analysis reveals a selective reduction in erythroid precursors. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pure red cell aplasia

Explanation:

The scenario of weakness, fatigue, low haemoglobin, low reticulocyte count, normal WBC and platelet counts, and bone marrow showing a selective reduction in erythroid precursors is consistent with Pure Red Cell Alasia (PRCA), which is characterized by a marked reduction or absence of red blood cell precursors while other hematopoietic cell lines remain normal.

  • It is a primary marrow disorder in which only erythroid progenitors are suppressed (red cell progenitors are completely absent in severe cases).
  • Causes:
    • Associated with neoplasms (thymoma and large granular lymphocytic leukaemia)
    • Drug exposures
    • Autoimmune disorders
    • Parvovirus infection
  • Clinical features: Fatigue, weakness, pallor, frequent infections, easy bruising or bleeding, and shortness of breath due to insufficient production of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.
  • It features a marked reduction or absence of red blood cell precursors while other hematopoietic cell lines remain normal.

Aplastic anaemia (Option A) is a rare condition where the bone marrow fails to produce sufficient red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets, leading to fatigue, infections, and bleeding. It can be caused by autoimmune diseases, infections, medications, or toxins. It involves a reduction in all hematopoietic cell lines and a hypocellular marrow with increased fat content on bone marrow biopsy.

Iron deficiency anaemia (Option C) is a common type of anaemia caused by insufficient iron, leading to reduced haemoglobin production. Symptoms include fatigue, pallor, and weakness. It presents with low haemoglobin, low MCH, low MCV, low MCV, and high reticulocyte count, and it often shows signs of microcytic anaemia on blood smears.

Pernicious anaemia (Option D) is a type of vitamin B12 deficiency anaemia caused by impaired absorption of B12 due to a lack of intrinsic factors. It leads to symptoms like fatigue, weakness, and neurological issues. It features low haemoglobin, high MCV, high MCH, and Erythroid hyperplasia on bone marrow biopsy.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with Vitamin A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bitot’s spots

Explanation:

Causes for Vitamin A Deficiency :

  • Decreased intake.
  • Obstructive jaundice: Defective absorption.
  • Liver cirrhosis: Reduce synthesis of RBP (retinol binding protein).
  • Severe malnutrition: Lack of amino acids for RBP synthesis.
  • Chronic nephrosis: RBP excretion through urine.

Vitamin A Deficiency Manifestations :

1. Ocular manifestations :

  • Vitamin A deficiency is the most significant preventable cause of blindness, especially in children below 5 in developing countries.
  • Early Signs:
    • Loss of sensitivity to green light.
    • Difficulty adapting to dim light.
    • Night blindness.
  • Prolonged Deficiency:
    • Xerophthalmia:
      • Dry, thick, keratinized conjunctiva and cornea. If untreated, it leads to corneal ulceration and ultimately results in blindness due to the formation of opaque scar tissue.
      • WHO grading of xerophthalmia:
      • Bitot's Spots: Grayish-white triangular plaques firmly adherent to the conjunctiva.
      • Keratomalacia: When xerophthalmia persists for a longer time, it progresses to keratomalacia (corneal softening).

XN
  • Night blindness.

X1
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis.
  • X1B: Bitot spots. (Option B)

X2
  • Corneal xerosis.

X3
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration, less than one-third.
  • X3B: Corneal ulceration, more than one-third.

XS
  • Corneal scar.

XF
  • Xerophthalmic fundus.

2. Immune Function:

  • Deficiency increases susceptibility to infections.
  • Infection reduces retinol-binding protein synthesis, lowering vitamin A levels and impairing immune responses.

3. Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions:

  • Follicular Hyperkeratosis (Phrynoderma): Causes rough skin due to hyperkeratinization of the follicular epithelium.
  • Keratinizing Metaplasia: Affects respiratory, gastrointestinal, and genitourinary tracts.
  • Epithelium is atrophied.

4. Other General Manifestation :

  • Growth retardation due to defective synthesis of chondroitin sulfate.
  • Decreased protein synthesis.

Incorrect Options:

Pinguecula (Option A) is a degenerative conjunctival condition unrelated to Vitamin A deficiency.

Pterygium (Option C) is a fibrovascular growth extending from the conjunctiva onto the cornea, often caused by UV exposure rather than nutritional deficiency.

Stocker’s line (Option D) is an iron line seen in front of the advancing edge of a pterygium, also unrelated to Vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters decreases acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Albumin

Explanation:

During acute inflammation, the liver increases the production of positive acute-phase reactants like C-reactive protein (CRP) (Option A), hepcidin (Option B), and fibrinogen (Option C), which help in immune response and coagulation.

However, albumin is a negative acute-phase reactant, meaning its levels decrease during inflammation as the liver prioritizes synthesizing proteins involved in the inflammatory response.

 

  • They are plasma proteins, mostly synthesized in the liver, whose plasma concentrations may increase several hundred–fold as part of the response to inflammatory stimuli.
  • Few of these examples are:
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) (Option A ruled out)
    • Fibrinogen (Option C ruled out)
    • Serum amyloid A (SAA) protein.
    • Hepcidin (Option B ruled out)
    • Thrombopoietin
  • These are increased during the process of inflammation.

questions.text: Which nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sixth nerve

Explanation:

Nerves of the eye:

Optic nerve (CN II)
  • Purely sensory
  • Senses the incoming light and image displayed on retina

Oculomotor nerve (CN III) (Option C)
  • Innervates majority of the extraocular muscles
  • Motor innervation to the superior rectus muscle, medial rectus muscle, inferior rectus muscle, inferior oblique muscle, levator palpebrae superioris muscle, ciliary muscle, and the sphincter muscle.

Trochlear nerve (CN IV) (Option D)
  • Motor innervation to the superior oblique muscle

Trigeminal Nerve (CN V)

  • Ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to the eye
  • Afferent part of corneal and lacrimation reflex

Abducens Nerve (CN VI) (Option A)

  • Motor innervation to the lateral rectus muscle

Facial Nerve (CN VII)
  • Motor innervation of the orbicularis oculi muscle
  • Efferent part of corneal and lacrimation reflex

Sympathetic Nervous System
  • Long ciliary nerves: Innervates the pupillary dilator muscles causing mydriasis

Parasympathetic nervous system
  • Short ciliary nerves: Innervates the sphincter pupillae muscles causing miosis

7th CN palsy (Option D) This nerve innervates facial muscles, not extraocular muscles.

questions.text: Oil drop cataract is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Galactosemia

Explanation:

Galactosemia cataracts cause oil drop cataract.

Galactosemia

Inborn error of galactose metabolism

Enzyme deficiency

  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GPUT)
  • Galactokinase (GK)

Type of cataract

  • Bilateral
  • “Oil droplet” (Option A)
  • Central lens

Features

  • May be reversed
  • May be prevented if milk and milk products are eliminated at an early stage

Wilson's disease (Option B) primarily affects the liver and brain, and produces sunflower cataracts and Kayser-Fleischer ring in the cornea.

Gaucher's disease and Tay-Sachs (Option C and D) disease are lysosomal storage disorders and are not associated with oil drop cataracts.

questions.text: Identify the device.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lippes Loop

Explanation:

The image shows a Lippes Loop, which is a 1st generation IUD. It has a characteristic S-shaped design made of plastic.

Lippe’s Loop

 

Features of Lippes Loop:
  • Non-medicated device
  • Has a high failure rate

Mechanism of Action:
  • Foreign body reaction
  • Cellular/Biochemical changes in endometrium/uterine fluids
  • Impair viability of gamete
  • Reduce chances of fertilization, rather than implantation

Mirena and Progestasert (Options A & D): These are 3rd Generation IUDs containing hormones, specifically progesterone. They have a different T-shaped design.

Copper T (Option C): A 2nd Generation IUD that contains copper and has a T-shaped design, unlike the S-shaped device shown.

questions.text: A patient with elevated calcium and normal alkaline phosphatase undergoes a skull X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Multiple myeloma

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of a patient with elevated calcium, normal alkaline phosphatase, and osteolytic lesions on a skull X-ray suggests Multiple Myeloma.
  • It is a plasma cell neoplasm associated with (Mnemonic: CRAB features with immune abnormalities)
    • C - Hypercalcemia
    • R - Renal failure
    • A - Anaemia
    • B - Lytic bone lesions, and
    • Immune abnormalities.

Antibodies in Multiple Myeloma:

Monoclonal Immunoglobulins

Free Light Chains
  • IgG: Most common (55% of patients).
  • IgA: Seen in 25% of cases.
  • IgM, IgD, IgE: Less common.
  • Often produced in excess, these are called Bence Jones proteins.
  • It can cause myeloma kidney (renal disease).

Pathogenesis of Multiple Myeloma:

  • There are 3 main cytogenetic abnormalities seen in MM.
    • Deletion of chromosome 13q (also seen in CLL).
    • Translocation t (11;14) (also seen in mantle cell lymphoma).
    • Deletion of chromosome 17p (TP53).
    • IL-6 is essential for plasma cell growth, and its elevated levels are linked to poor prognosis.

Clinical features:

  • It is seen in patients 60-70 years of age.
  • Increased osteoclastic activity leads to bone resorption hypercalcemia and lytic punched-out lesions.
  • Decreased osteoblastic activity (Normal or ↓ ALP levels).

Multiple Punched-out Osteolytic Lesions on the Lateral Skull Radiograph in a patient with Multiple Myeloma

 

Grave’s disease (Option A) is an autoimmune disorder that causes hyperthyroidism, characterised by an overactive thyroid gland. It results in symptoms like weight loss, heat intolerance, tremors, and bulging eyes (exophthalmos). It is caused by autoantibodies that stimulate the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor. It involves thyroid hormone imbalance and does not typically cause hypercalcemia or specific bone lesions on X-ray.

Paget’s disease (Option B) is a bone disorder marked by abnormal bone remodelling, leading to enlarged and weakened bones. It causes bone pain, deformities, and fractures with elevated alkaline phosphatase levels. It typically causes elevated alkaline phosphatase due to abnormal bone remodelling.


Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) (Option D) is a bone marrow cancer characterised by excessive white blood cell production and the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome. It typically causes fatigue, weight loss, and splenomegaly but does not present with hypercalcemia or lytic bone lesions.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with intermenstrual spotting during the first month after IUCD insertion. She has no other complications. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Observation and reassurance

Explanation:Intermenstrual spotting during the first month after IUCD insertion is a common occurrence. When there are no additional symptoms or complications, the most appropriate management is observation and reassurance.

Iron supplements and reassurance (Option A): Iron supplements are unnecessary unless anemia is evident. Spotting alone doesn't warrant supplementation

Remove the IUCD (Option B) is unnecessary unless the patient develops severe complications or requests its removal.

Oral antibiotics (Option D) are not indicated unless there are signs of infection.

questions.text: Which is the type of cataract seen following a blunt trauma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rosette cataract

Explanation:

Traumatic cataract: blunt trauma: Rosette cataract (Option A)

  • It is a cortical cataract that starts from the posterior cortex.

Toxic cataract:

  • Steroids - Prolonged use in high doses may cause posterior subcapsular cataracts. Children are more susceptible
  • Other causes of posterior subcapsular cataract: Galactosemia, Myotonic dystrophy, BLUNT trauma, complicated cataract, chloroquine, busulfan, NF2,
  • Glaucoma by TOPICAL steroids and cataract by SYSTEMIC STEROIDS (mnemonic: GTCS)
  • Miotics - Especially long-acting cholinesterase inhibitors such as echothiophate, demecarium bromide, and diisopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) may cause anterior subcapsular-granular cataracts
  • Other causes of anterior subcapsular cataract - Amiodarone, chlorpromazine, busulfan, gold, and allopurinol
  • AACG ( Mnemonic): Atopic dermatitis- shield cataract, Amiodarone, Chlorpromazine, Gold deposit, AACG(acute angle closure glaucoma)

Radiation cataract: Infrared (heat) cataract-

  • Infrared aka glassblower cataract
  • Lens capsule exfoliation with discoid posterior opacities
  • X-ray, gamma rays, neutron exposure: Inadequately protected technicians, patients treated for malignant tumors, and workers of atomic energy plants are at risk.

Electric Shock cataract/ Lightening cataract: It leads to Stellate ASC

Incorrect Options:

Christmas tree cataract (Option B) is associated with Myotonic Dystrophy.

Snowflake cataract (Option C) Diabetes mellitus is associated with Snowflake cataract

Sunflower cataract (Option D) is associated with Wilson’s disease

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, 10 years after mastectomy, notices gradual swelling and heaviness in her right upper limb without pain. On examination, bluish nodules on the skin with no infections are noted. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lymphangiosarcoma

Explanation:

  • Lymphangiosarcoma is the most likely cause of these symptoms, especially in a patient with a history of mastectomy.
  • This condition, also known as Stewart-Treves syndrome, can develop years after mastectomy due to long-standing lymphedema, which is a consequence of lymphatic obstruction.

Complications of mastectomy:

Complications

Explanations

Lymphedema

Swelling is caused by the accumulation of lymph fluid in the arm or chest wall due to the removal of lymph nodes.(After MRM and axillary dissection)

Wound infection/Flap necrosis

Postoperative infections where blackening of suture line is seen (flap necrosis), if necrosed site note removed, leads to wound infection

Post-Mastectomy Pain Syndrome

Chronic pain in the chest or upper arm due to nerve damage or scar tissue formation.

Nerve Injuries
  • Long thoracic nerve- injury leads to winging of the scapula
  • Thoracodorsal nerve

Lymphangiosarcoma
  • Stewart-Treves syndrome - Cancerous growth in the lymphatic vessels, often associated with long-standing lymphedema.
  • After an average of 10.5 years following MRM and radiotherapy, the patient develops angiosarcoma

Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (Option B) is characterised by symptoms such as pain, paraesthesia, oedema, cyanosis, cold extremities, and weakness in the hands.

Chronic Venous Insufficiency (Option C) typically presents with postural discomfort, varicose veins, oedema, skin pigmentation, induration, dermatitis, lipodermatosclerosis, and ulceration.

Recurrent Breast Cancer (Option D) usually presents with a palpable lump, nipple retraction, swelling of lymph nodes, and signs of metastasis.

questions.text: Which nerve defect causes lagophthalmos?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 7th nerve

Explanation:

  • Lagophthalmos is the inability to close the eye.
  • It is a feature of 7th nerve palsy.
  • Neuroparalytic keratitis can occur due to seventh nerve palsy, resulting in lagophthalmos from affected orbicularis oculi and leading to exposure keratitis

Bell’s palsy:

Description
  • Most common cause of facial palsy
  • Characterized by idiopathic, LMN facial paralysis of acute onset
  • Most commonly the Labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve is involved.
  • Males and females are equally affected.

Aetiology
  • Idiopathic: Most common cause
  • Viral Infection: HSV >> Herpes zoster
  • Vascular Ischemia
  • Hereditary: Positive family history in 6-8%
  • Autoimmune

Risk Factors
  • More common in diabetics (due to angiopathy) and pregnant women (due to fluid retention).

Clinical Features
  • Sudden onset of facial paralysis with inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon) (Option A), asymmetry of the face, epiphora, drooping mouth, and dribbling of saliva.
  • Associated symptoms may include ear pain, noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis), or loss of taste (chorda tympani involvement).

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is made by excluding other causes of peripheral facial paralysis.

Treatment
  • General: Reassurance, pain relief, eye protection and physiotherapy
  • Medical: Prednisolone 60 mg per day for 5 days then reduced by 10 mg per day (for a total treatment time of 10 days) and 50 mg per day (in two divided doses) for 10 days, Acyclovir
  • Surgical: Nerve decompression

Prognosis
  • 85%-90% of patients fully recover
  • Incomplete resolution are mainly seen in recurrent/late recovery cases

Incorrect Options:

6th nerve (Option B) leads to lateral rectus muscle paralysis, causing impaired abduction.

4th nerve (Option C) affects the superior oblique muscle, resulting in vertical diplopia.

5th nerve (Option D) is responsible for facial sensation and corneal reflex, but not eyelid closure.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of ERCP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pancreatitis

Explanation:

  • Pancreatitis is the most common complication of ERCP, with an incidence of approximately 4.3%. While post-ERCP pancreatitis is typically mild, it can become severe with extensive pancreatic necrosis in some cases.

Complications of ERCP:

  • Pancreatitis (Most Common)
    • It can be severe, with extensive pancreatic necrosis
    • Associated with a significant mortality rate
    • Use of per-rectal indometacin/diclofenac to reduce risk
  • Duodenal perforation (Option A)
  • Haemorrhage post-sphincterotomy (Option C)
  • Sepsis
  • Cholangitis (Option B)
  • Sphincter stenosis

questions.text: How does the World Health Organization (WHO) define blindness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) VA < 3/60

Explanation:

NPCB Classification of Visual Impairment

The National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India defines blindness as "visual acuity of <3/60 in a better eye with best possible correction" and central visual field <10 degrees. The NPCB further categorizes visual impairment as:

Classification

Visual Acuity

Visual Impairment

Visual acuity of less than 6/18 in the better eye with available correction

Low Vision

Visual acuity of less than 6/18 to 6/60

Economic Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 6/60 to 3/60

Social Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 3/60 to 1/60

Manifest Blindness

Visual acuity of less than 1/60 to the perception of light

Absolute Blindness

No perception of light


 

WHO Classification of Visual Impairment

The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as "visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent".(Option A)

The International Classification of Disease 11 (2018) classifies vision impairment into distance and near-presenting vision impairment

Classification

Visual Acuity

Mild Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12

Moderate Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18

Severe Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60

Blindness

Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60

Near Vision Impairment

Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or M0.8 at 40 cm with existing correction

Option B,C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with irregular periods, acne, excessive hair growth, and increased serum insulin and testosterone levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations of the patient indicate Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS).

  • PCOS is the most common endocrine disorder among women of reproductive age.
  • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome, is a heterogeneous, multisystem endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age with ovarian expression of various metabolic disturbances.
  • Characteristic presentation includes:
    • Irregular menstrual cycles
    • Hirsutism (excessive hair growth)
    • Acne
    • Signs of insulin resistance
    • Elevated serum testosterone levels
  • PCOS is the leading cause of hirsutism in women.
  • Endometriosis (Option B): Endometriosis primarily presents with dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, and infertility. The absence of these symptoms and presence of hyperandrogenism rules out this diagnosis. Additionally, endometriosis does not cause elevated testosterone or insulin resistance.
  • Ovarian Tumor (Option C): While ovarian tumors can cause hormonal imbalances, they typically present with more acute onset of symptoms and often include pelvic pain or bloating. The chronic nature of symptoms and classic presentation of PCOS make this diagnosis less likely.
  • Hypothyroidism (Option D): Hypothyroidism presents with fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, and often hair thinning rather than excessive hair growth. It does not cause elevated testosterone levels or the androgenic symptoms seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. Which of the following should be avoided in the management of the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Administration of 5% dextrose

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation suggests acute pancreatitis. In managing acute pancreatitis, administration of 5% dextrose should be avoided in the initial phase because it can excessively increase blood glucose levels.
  • Elevated glucose can stimulate the pancreas and worsen the condition by increasing pancreatic activity. This can exacerbate inflammation and further damage the pancreas.

Acute pancreatitis:

  • Clinical features:
    • Pain (severe, constant, and often resistant to common analgesics).
    • In about 50% of patients, the pain radiates to the back, and some patients may find relief by sitting or leaning forward.
    • Nausea and vomiting are usually prominent, and retching may persist even with nasogastric aspiration.
  • Examination findings:
    • Patient's condition: well to severely ill with signs of shock and toxicity.
    • Tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension are commonly observed.
    • Mild icterus may suggest biliary obstruction (in gallstone pancreatitis).
    • SIRS may be present
    • Bluish discolouration (Grey Turner’s sign or Cullen’s sign).
    • Abdominal distension due to ileus or ascites is common, and muscle guarding is often present.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serum amylase level > 3x the normal value is strongly indicative.
    • Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than amylase.
    • CECT scan is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Management:
    • Mild cases may be managed with IV fluids, analgesics, and antiemetics.
    • Nil per oral
    • (NPO) is typically advised initially to avoid stimulating the pancreas.
    • Antibiotics are not generally indicated unless there is suspicion of infection
  • Management of severe cases:
    • Admit to intensive care or a high-dependency unit for close monitoring.
    • Aggressive fluid resuscitation is critical, guided by vital signs, urine output, and central venous pressure.
    • Oxygen supplementation and serial blood gas analysis.
    • If nutritional support is necessary, enteral feeding via nasogastric tube is preferred over parenteral nutrition.
  • Management of specific complications:
    • Antibiotics may be indicated if cholangitis or other infections are suspected. Prophylactic antibiotics should not exceed 14 days.
    • If gallstone pancreatitis is suspected and there is biliary obstruction, ERCP should be performed within 72 hours.
  • Complications:
