    • Shock, arrhythmias, ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome), renal failure, and DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation).
    • Metabolic derangements like hypocalcemia, hyperglycemia, and hyperlipidemia may occur.
    • Peripancreatic fluid collection, pancreatic abscess, pseudocyst, and pancreatic necrosis.
    • Pleural effusion, pancreatic ascites, and pancreatic haemorrhage (pseudoaneurysm) are also common.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presents with lower back pain and fever. During history-taking, he mentions experiencing similar episodes in the past with amylase levels being elevated. Which type of necrosis is likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fat necrosis

Explanation:

  • The symptoms of lower back pain, fever, recurrent episodes, and elevated amylase levels suggest Pancreatitis, which is associated with fat necrosis.
  • It is divided into two forms, acute and chronic, both of which are initiated by injuries that lead to autodigestion of the pancreas by its own enzymes.
  • Histopathological examination:
    • Gross: Fat and parenchymal necrosis with saponification.

  • Microscopic: Interstitial inflammation, edema, fat necrosis, vessel wall damage, and haemorrhage.

Fibrinoid necrosis (Option A) is associated with antigen-antibody reactions (immune complex deposition).

  • Some examples are:
    • Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN)
    • Rheumatic Heart Disease (RHD) shows Aschoff Bodies.
    • SLE
    • Malignant Hypertension (HTN)

Coagulative necrosis (Option C) is characteristic of solid organs such as the kidney, liver, and heart (most common). It typically occurs due to ischemic infarction, leading to the preservation of tissue architecture despite cell death. Infarcts in these organs are often wedge-shaped, reflecting the vascular supply pattern.

Liquefaction necrosis (Option D) occurs in tissues rich in hydrolytic enzymes, leading to loss of structural integrity. Also known as colliquative necrosis, it results in complete tissue disintegration without preserved architecture.

questions.text: Where is the Bartholin gland located?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Posterior 1/3rd of labia majora

Explanation:

  • The Bartholin gland, also known as the greater vestibular gland, is located at the junction of the anterior 2/3rd and posterior 1/3rd of the vulva.
  • These glands function to provide lubrication to the vagina during intercourse.
  • The gland's epithelium varies:
    • Gland: columnar epithelium
    • Duct: stratified squamous epithelium
    • Terminal part of duct: transitional epithelium

Bartholin Cyst:

  • Develops when the gland's duct becomes blocked
  • Can become infected, leading to an abscess
  • Often caused by mixed infections, including Staphylococcus aureus

Treatment Options:

  • Drainage using a Word catheter
  • Marsupialization - cyst is incised and edges are everted
  • Excision is generally not advised unless absolutely necessary

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden painful decrease in vision and a fixed, vertically oval pupil. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acute congestive glaucoma

Explanation:

  • Acute congestive glaucoma is characterized by sudden painful decrease in vision and fixed vertically oval pupil
  • Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma (APAC) after an attack has been resolved.
  • The triad helps in identifying damage caused during the acute episode.

Features of APAC:

  • Descemet membrane folds
  • Iris atrophy
  • Irregular pupil (Option C)
  • Glaucomflecken
  • Cataract
  • Cupping +/-

Vogt’s triad:

It may be seen in both treated and non-treated cases after an attack of acute PAC. It is characterized by:

  1. Slightly dilated non-reacting pupil (due to sphincter atrophy)
  2. Glaucomflecken (anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity)
  3. Patches of iris atrophy

 

Incorrect Options:

Macular degeneration (Option A):

  • It is characterized by irreversible loss of vision
  • Fixed oval pupils is not a feature of this condition

Optic neuritis (Option B) are normal in Optic neuritis
Acute anterior uveitis (Option D) is characterized by a dilated, festooned-shaped pupil

questions.text: A 26-year-old nulligravida presents with no cystocele and no rectocele but has a third-degree uterine prolapse. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Abdominal sling surgery

Explanation:

  • Abdominal sling surgery, also known as sacrohysteropexy or uterine suspension, involves using a synthetic mesh or native tissue to support the uterus by attaching it to the sacrum.
  • This approach is beneficial for young women with uterine prolapse who wish to preserve their fertility and sexual function.
  • Abdominal sling surgery, also known as sacrohysteropexy or uterine suspension, involves using a synthetic mesh or native tissue to support the uterus by attaching it to the sacrum.
  • This approach is beneficial for young women with uterine prolapse who wish to preserve their fertility and sexual function.

Category of patient

Treatment of Uterine Prolapse

Nulliparous or congenital prolapse

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation

Pregnancy & postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks POG)
  • Pelvic floor exercises

<40 Years
  • Fothergill’s repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar’s procedure

>40 Years - with completed family

Vaginal hysterectomy & pelvic floor repair

>60 Years - unit for surgery
  • Le-fort’s repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn’t want to retain sexual function

Degrees of uterine prolapse:

First degree

The uterus descends downward, but the external os (opening of the cervix) remains inside the vagina.

Second degree

The uterine body remains inside the vagina while the external os protrudes outside the vaginal introitus.

Third degree (Procidentia)

The cervix, uterine body, and fundus descend to lie outside the introitus.

The complete uterus protrudes outside the vagina.

LeFort Colpocleisis (Option A ) is a surgical procedure often used for older women who no longer desire vaginal intercourse. This procedure involves closing the vaginal canal partially to provide support for the prolapsed uterus. It is not suitable for young, nulliparous women who might want to preserve their fertility and sexual function.

Fothergill operation (Option B) also known as the Manchester procedure, is a surgical technique that involves amputation of the cervix and suspension of the uterus. While it preserves the uterus, it may not be the best option for severe third-degree prolapse in a young woman, particularly if future pregnancy is a consideration.

Shirodkar procedure (Option C) is typically used for cervical incompetence and involves the placement of a cervical cerclage to prevent preterm birth. It is not an appropriate treatment for uterine prolapse.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with a history of decreased fetal movements and respiratory distress in her newborn. On examination, the neonate appeared cyanotic, with increased breathing work. Auscultation reveals bowel sounds in the left hemithorax. A chest x-ray is given in the image. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

Explanation:

The history provided, along with the chest X-ray showing multiple air-fluid levels above the diaphragm, strongly suggests a diagnosis of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).

 

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia: CDH is a birth defect with an abnormal opening in the diaphragm, allowing abdominal organs to move into the chest cavity and severely impair lung development.

  • Most Common Side: Left (84%) > Right
  • It is of two types:
    • Bochdalek hernia is the most common type of CDH due to the failure of the development of the pleuroperitoneal canal.
    • Morgagni Hernia is due to the defective Central tendon.

 

Difference between Bochdalek and Morgagni Hernia:

Feature

Bochdalek Hernia

Morgagni Hernia

Side

Left-sided

Right-sided

Location

Posterolateral

Anteromedial

Herniated Organs

Small intestine, stomach

Transverse colon, sometimes liver

Common Symptoms

Scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress, mediastinal shift

Mostly Asymptomatic and Incidental

Diagnostic Features
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Pulmonary hypertension

Less severe respiratory distress

Association

Polyhydramnios, abnormal LHR, and liver position

Rarely detected prenatally; usually diagnosed later

Management

Variable

Generally Better prognosis

 Incorrect Options:

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option B) The chest X-ray in Tetralogy of Fallot typically shows a boot-shaped heart.

Transposition of the great vessels (Option C) The chest X-ray for transposition of the great vessels shows an "egg-on-a-string" appearance of the heart.

Tracheoesophageal fistula (Option D) In tracheoesophageal fistula, a chest X-ray will often show a coiled nasogastric tube in the upper esophageal pouch.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct definition of postpartum pyrexia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) After 24 hours, temperature > 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit

 

Explanation:

Postpartum pyrexia, also known as puerperal fever, occurs after delivery and has specific diagnostic criteria.

 

Definition:

  • Temperature > 100.4°F (38°C)
  • Occurs between first to tenth day postpartum
  • Must be present on at least two occasions
  • First 24 hours postpartum are excluded

 

Clinical Significance:

  • Important marker for postpartum infections
  • Requires careful monitoring and evaluation
  • Early detection prevents serious complications

 

Option B (After 6 hours), Option C (After 3 hours), and Option D (After 12 hours) are incorrect as the first 24 hours postpartum must be excluded when defining postpartum pyrexia.

questions.text: During an endoscopy, a man is found to have the squamocolumnar junction located more proximally than normal. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sliding hernia

 

Explanation:

Sliding hernia is the most likely cause of the squamocolumnar junction being located more proximally than normal. This condition involves the upward displacement of the gastroesophageal junction into the thorax, which can result in the squamocolumnar junction appearing higher during an endoscopic examination.

 

Hiatus Hernia: Condition in which the abdominal contents pass through the hiatal opening of the diaphragm into the mediastinum.

 

Types

Description

Type I/Sliding Hiatus Hernia

The most common type.

The gastroesophageal junction and part of the stomach slide up through the diaphragm.

Type II/Paraesophageal Hiatus Hernia

Part of the stomach pushes through the diaphragm next to the oesophagus. The gastroesophageal junction remains in place.

Type III/Mixed Hiatus Hernia

Combines features of both sliding and paraesophageal hernias.

Type IV

Involves viscera other than the stomach in the hernial sac, like the colon.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Achalasia cardia (Option A) typically causes failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, leading to a dilated esophagus and difficulties with swallowing, but it doesn't affect the position of the squamocolumnar junction.

Rolling hernia (Option C) (also called paraesophageal hernias) involves part of the stomach rolling into the chest beside the esophagus, but this does not typically affect the position of the squamocolumnar junction.

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) (Option D) is associated with acid reflux and damage to the esophagus but does not cause the squamocolumnar junction to move proximally.

Clinical Features: Heartburn, regurgitation of food, chest pain.

Diagnosis: Barium swallow X-Ray, Esophageal manometry.

Treatment: PPI, Nissen Fundoplication, Hernia repair.

questions.text: What could be the cause of sudden painless loss of vision?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Central serous retinopathy

Explanation:

  • Central serous retinopathy is characterized by sudden painless loss of vision. The other causes of sudden painless loss of vision are as follows:
    • Optic neuritis
    • Methyl alcohol amblyopia
    • Nonischaemic central retinal vein occlusion.

Central Serous Chorioretinopathy (CSCR) (Option D)

  • CSCR is characterized by the spontaneous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region, with or without retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) detachment.

Pathogenesis: Increased sympathetic drive and corticosteroids affect choroidal vascular permeability, raising hydrostatic pressure, and leading to RPE defects and serous detachment of the neurosensory retina.

Risk Factors:

  • Males aged 20-50
  • Type A personality, Emotional stress, Steroid use
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus, Cushing's disease
  • Pregnancy (3rd trimester)

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Sudden painless vision loss (6/9 - 6/24)
  • Relative positive scotoma, micropsia, and metamorphopsia
  • Recurrence in 30-50% of cases

Examination Findings:

  • Mild macular elevation with circular ring reflex
  • RPE detachment (yellow-grey elevations)
  • Absence or distortion of the foveal reflex
  • Subretinal deposits

Investigations:

  • Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA): Shows "ink-blot" or "smoke-stack" leakage patterns.
  • Indocyanine green (ICG): Shows hyperfluorescence due to choroidal hyperpermeability.
  • OCT: Shows neurosensory retinal and RPE detachment.

 

Treatment:

  1. Conservative: Reassurance; spontaneous resolution in 80-90% of cases within 1-6 months.
  2. Laser Photocoagulation: For cases lasting more than 3 months, recurrent cases, and those with permanent vision loss in the other eye due to CSCR.
  3. Photodynamic Therapy (PDT): For severe, sub-foveal leaks, or chronic cases.
  4. Anti-VEGF: Considered if choroidal neovascularization (CNV) develops.

Incorrect Options:

Chemical injuries to the eyeball and acute congestive glaucoma (Option A and B) typically present with pain.

Acute iridocyclitis (Option C) is associated with pain, photophobia, and redness, rather than painless vision loss.

questions.text: Which appendicular carcinoma is most commonly associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mucinous cystadenoma

Explanation:

Pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is a rare condition characterized by the accumulation of mucinous material in the peritoneal cavity, often caused by a rupture of a mucin-producing tumor like Mucinous cystadenoma.

Pseudomyxoma Peritonei (PMP) is a rare, life-threatening condition characterized by progressive peritoneal tumour deposits, mucinous ascites, omental cake, and ovarian involvement. It is most commonly caused by the rupture of a mucinous appendiceal tumour. Symptoms include abdominal distension, anorexia, and bowel dysfunction.

  • Classification: PMP is graded based on cytological atypia in peritoneal deposits:
    • Acellular mucin
    • Low-grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei
    • High-grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei
    • High-grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei with signet ring cells

Treatment: The standard approach is Cytoreductive Surgery (CRS) combined with Hyperthermic Intraperitoneal Chemotherapy (HIPEC). This extensive surgery, including organ removals, aims for complete tumour clearance. Survival rates after complete cytoreduction are 87% at 5 years and 70% at 10 years.

Chemotherapy may be used for high-grade, unresectable cases or post-surgery in high-risk patients.

questions.text: What does the given pedigree chart indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mitochondrial Disorder

Explanation:

  • The given pedigree suggests a Mitochondrial Disorder, where a defect in maternal mtDNA is inherited by all offspring, while a defect in paternal mtDNA is not passed on to any offspring.
  • They involve defects in the mitochondria, which are responsible for producing energy in the form of ATP through oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited exclusively from the mother (females with pathogenic mtDNA can pass the disease to their offspring).
  • They affect organs with prominent aerobic metabolism (commonly skeletal muscle (myopathy) and nervous system).
  • Some examples are:
    • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON)
    • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO)/ Kearns-Sayre syndrome (KSS)
    • Leigh syndrome
    • Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS)
    • Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibres (MERRF)
    • Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP)
    • Primary coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10) deficiency
  • The most common mitochondrial disease is MELAS.
  • The most common mitochondrial Myopathy is CPEO (Chronic Progressive External Ophthalmoplegia).

Autosomal Dominant (AD) (Option A) inheritance follows a vertical transmission pattern, where an affected individual has an affected parent, and there is a 50% chance of passing the dominant trait to offspring, with both males and females equally affected.

Autosomal Recessive (AR) (Option B) inheritance shows horizontal transmission, with the trait appearing in siblings while parents are unaffected, often in consanguineous marriages. Carriers have a 25% chance of an affected child, and males and females are equally affected. It includes most inborn errors of metabolism.

X-linked Recessive (XLR) (Option D) inheritance means females (XX) are carriers, while males are affected by the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best post-coital contraceptive method?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Levonorgestrel (LNG)

Explanation: Levonorgestrel (LNG) is the drug of choice for emergency contraception.

Key Features:

  • Contains progesterone
  • Known as the drug of choice (DOC) for emergency contraception
  • Trade name: iPill

Advantages:

  • Least side effects among available options
  • Single pill administration
  • No interference with menstrual cycle

Dosage:

  • 0.75 mg × 2 tablets taken immediately (stat)
  • Alternative: 0.75 mg 1 tablet stat and another after 12 hours
  • Single 1.5 mg tablet commonly used

Estrogen (Option B): Estrogen alone is not recommended for emergency contraception due to its significant side effect profile including nausea and thromboembolic event.

Norethisterone (Option C): This progestin is primarily indicated for menstrual disorders and is not approved for emergency contraception.

Ulipristal acetate (Option D): While effective for up to 120 hours post-intercourse, ulipristal acetate is not considered the first-line emergency contraceptive. It requires prescription, has more contraindications, and is more expensive than levonorgestrel.

questions.text: Which of the following is the treatment of choice in a pregnant woman with an anal wart, as shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen

Explanation:

The image suggests a diagnosis of condyloma acuminata, which is the most common sexually transmitted anal disease caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). Cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen is the treatment of choice for removing anal warts in pregnant women.

  • The advantage of cryotherapy is that it is relatively bloodless, painless, and allows precise control over the depth and extent of freezing.

Condylomata Acuminata (Genital Warts): Genital warts are caused by infection with human papillomavirus (HPV) and are transmitted sexually. HPV infection is common, but only a small proportion of infected individuals develop visible warts. HPV types 6 and 11 are the most common causes of genital warts, and these types are not linked to cervical cancer.

  • Genital warts are distinct from ordinary skin warts, as they tend to be softer, moister, and more often pedunculated.
  • In women, warts are typically seen on the vulva and may line the vagina or appear on the cervix. Perianal warts are also common.
  • Treatment Options:
    • Podophyllin is a commonly used topical treatment. It is applied directly to the wart and carefully washed off after about 6 hours.
    • An alternative chemical treatment is imiquimod.
    • If chemical treatments are ineffective, other methods include cryosurgery, electrosurgery, laser ablation, or surgical excision.
    • Circumcision may be recommended in cases of extensive lesions under the foreskin.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Eye speculum

Explanation:

  • An eye speculum is a surgical instrument used to hold the eyelids apart during ophthalmic procedures. It ensures proper exposure of the eye, facilitating examination or surgery, like enucleation.

Eye speculum

Doyen’s speculum (Option B) used in Gynaecology

Universal retractor (Option A) and Mouth clamp (Option C) are used in Dentistry

questions.text: For how long is exclusive breastfeeding recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 6 months

Explanation: The recommended duration for exclusive breastfeeding is 6 months.

Exclusive Breastfeeding:

  • Only breast milk for the first 6 months
  • No additional food or drinks
  • Exceptions: oral rehydration solutions, drops/syrups of vitamins, minerals, or medicines
  • Provides optimal nutrition and health benefits to infant

3 months (Option A): While three months of exclusive breastfeeding provides some benefits, it is insufficient for optimal infant development. According to protocol, continuing exclusive breastfeeding for a full six months is recommended.

Nine months (Option C): By nine months, infants should already be receiving complementary foods alongside breast milk . Exclusive breastfeeding at this stage would not meet the growing nutritional needs of the developing infant.

Twelve months (Option D): Although breastfeeding can continue for 12 months or longer, exclusive breastfeeding should not extend beyond six month. At this stage, infants require additional nutrients from complementary foods while continuing to receive breast milk.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is associated with the beaten bronze appearance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endothelial Layer

Explanation:

Fuchs Endothelial Corneal Dystrophy is strongly associated with the "beaten-metal" appearance on Descemet's membrane. It is a common type of endothelial dystrophy (Option A), particularly affecting older adults.

Option B,C and D are not involved Fusch’s endothelial dystrophy

questions.text: What are the contraindications for the use of ventouse (vacuum extraction) during delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Preterm

Explanation: Vacuum extraction, also known as ventouse, is contraindicated in preterm deliveries.

Key Features:

  • Vacuum pressure: 0.8 kg/cm² to 1.0 kg/cm² (600 to 800 mmHg)
  • Applied over 2-3 minutes
  • Main contraindication is preterm delivery due to increased risk of injury to the preterm infant's delicate skull and brain structures

 

Decreased bear down efforts (Option A): This is actually an indication rather than a contraindication for vacuum extraction. When maternal pushing efforts are insufficient, vacuum assistance can help achieve successful vaginal delivery.

Heart disease (Option B): Maternal heart disease is not a contraindication and may even be an indication for assisted delivery. Vacuum extraction can benefit cardiac patients by shortening the second stage of labor and reducing cardiovascular stress.

Dilatation > 8 cm (Option D): Greater cervical dilatation is not a contraindication to vacuum extraction. In fact, vacuum extraction is typically performed at full dilatation (10 cm) when progress has arrested despite adequate pushing efforts.

questions.text: In cases of suspected ectopic pregnancy, which hormone is typically measured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Beta hCG

Explanation: Human chorionic gonadotropin (Beta hCG) is the primary hormone measured in suspected ectopic pregnancy.

Key Features:

  • Normal pregnancy: Beta hCG doubles every 48-72 hours
  • Ectopic pregnancy: Slower increase in Beta hCG levels
  • Important diagnostic indicator

Estrogen (Option A): While estrogen levels do increase during pregnancy, they are not specific enough to diagnose ectopic pregnancy. Estrogen measurements cannot determine the location of a pregnancy or distinguish between normal and ectopic implantation.

Progesterone (Option B): Although progesterone levels can indicate pregnancy viability, they cannot differentiate between ectopic and intrauterine pregnancies. Low progesterone suggests a non-viable pregnancy but doesn't confirm its location.

LH (Option D): Luteinizing hormone is only relevant for ovulation and menstrual cycle regulation. It has no role in pregnancy diagnosis or location determination, making it unsuitable for ectopic pregnancy detection.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Dubin-Johnson syndrome

Explanation:

  • Dubin-Johnson Syndrome is associated with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • It is characterised by impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile due to a defect in the MRP2 transporter, leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Darkly pigmented liver (accumulation of epinephrine metabolite).

 

Syndromes of Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Disorder

Defect

Severity of Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1

(Option A ruled out)

Complete deficiency of UGT

Severe

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 2

(Option B ruled out)

Partial deficiency of UGT

Mild to moderate

Gilbert syndrome

(Option C ruled out)

Very mild deficiency of UGT

Mild, asymptomatic

Syndromes of Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Disorder

Defect

Gross Feature of liver

Dubin Johnson syndrome

(Option D)

Defect in canalicular MRP2 protein.

Pigmented liver (due to epinephrine metabolite).

Rotor syndrome

Defective ATP-dependent biliary excretion.

Non-pigmented liver.

questions.text: A 17-week pregnant woman presents with hypertension, with blood pressure measurements of 140/94 mmHg initially and 144/90 mmHg four hours later. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chronic Hypertension

Explanation: The patient has chronic hypertension based on presentation before 20 weeks of gestation.

Key Features:

  • Pre-existing hypertension presenting in early pregnancy
  • Persistent elevated blood pressure (>140/90 mmHg)
  • Diagnosis made before 20 weeks gestation

Gestational Hypertension (Option A): This requires new-onset hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation. The patient's presentation at 17 weeks excludes this diagnosis as gestational hypertension cannot be diagnosed in early pregnancy.

Acute on Chronic Hypertension (Option C): While the patient has hypertension, there is no evidence of an acute exacerbation as the blood pressure readings are stable. Acuteness in chronic hypertension would show a significant spike in blood pressure values.

Pre-eclampsia (Option D): Pre-eclampsia typically develops after 20 weeks of gestation and requires additional criteria such as proteinuria or evidence of end-organ dysfunction. The patient's early presentation and lack of other symptoms make this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, who is gravida 1, para 1, presents with intermenstrual bleeding for the past 1.5 months. What is the initial investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Urine pregnancy test

Explanation: Urine pregnancy test is the initial test of choice for intermenstrual bleeding evaluation.

Key Features:

  • Detects human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) in urine
  • Sensitivity: 60-70% (sensitive to 150 mIU of HCG)
  • Simple, non-invasive first-line test
  • Rules out pregnancy as cause of bleeding

Ultrasound of the abdomen (Option A): This is not the initial test of choice as it is less sensitive than other methods for early pregnancy detection. While useful for evaluating pelvic pathology, it should be performed after pregnancy status is determined.

Transvaginal ultrasound (Option B): Although TVS provides detailed imaging of the pelvic organs, it is a second-line investigation after a urine pregnancy test. It's more appropriate for evaluating structural causes of bleeding once pregnancy is ruled out.

Endometrial biopsy (Option D): This is an invasive procedure that should only be considered after ruling out pregnancy and completing less invasive investigations. Performing an endometrial biopsy without first confirming pregnancy status could be harmful if the patient is pregnant.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective enzyme in Acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) NADPH oxidase

Explanation:

  • NADPH oxidase is the most effective enzyme in acute inflammation.
  • The Phox gene produces it and is the key enzyme involved in phagocytosis.
  • Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are produced through the rapid assembly and activation of NADPH oxidase (phagocyte oxidase). This enzyme oxidises NADPH, transferring electrons to molecular oxygen and generating superoxide anion (O₂•).

Defensins (Option B) are small antimicrobial peptides that help eliminate pathogens, but they are not the main enzyme involved in acute inflammation.

Catalase (Option C) is an enzyme that decomposes hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) to protect cells from oxidative damage, but it is not the primary enzyme involved in the inflammatory response.


MPO (Myeloperoxidase) (Option D) is an enzyme present in neutrophils that utilises hydrogen peroxide (produced by NADPH oxidase) to generate hypochlorous acid (HOCl), a potent antimicrobial agent. However, the most critical enzyme in acute inflammation is NADPH oxidase.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest marker to rise in a case of myocardial infarction (MI)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Heart fatty acid binding protein

Explanation:

H-FABP(Heart fatty acid binding protein) is the earliest marker to rise in a case of myocardial infarction (MI).

Cardiac Markers

Cardiac Troponin

(Troponin T and I) (Option B ruled out)
  • Preferred biochemical markers due to their sensitivity and specificity.
  • Troponin levels:
    • Increase within 3-6 hours.
    • Peak at around 36 hours.
    • Remains elevated for 7-10 days after STEMI.
  • Troponin should be measured at presentation and repeated at 1-3 hours (high-sensitivity assays) or 3-6 hours (conventional assays).
  • Cardiac troponin levels remain elevated for several days after an acute myocardial infarction (AMI), making them unreliable for detecting reinfarction.

Creatine Phosphokinase (CK) and CK-MB

(Option A ruled out)
  • CK rises within 4-8 hours.
  • Peaks by 24 hours.
  • Returns to normal within 48-72 hours.
  • CK-MB elevated:
    • Cardiac surgery
    • Myocarditis
    • Electrical cardioversion
  • CK-MB levels normalise within 48 to 72 hours, so a subsequent rise can confirm reinfarction.

Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH) (Option C ruled out)
  • Increase in the blood 6 to 12 hours after ACS.
  • Peak within 24 to 72 hours.
  • Normalise within 8 to 14 days.
  • LDH is no longer used to diagnose myocardial infarction because it is not specific to cardiac myocytes.

Heart-type Fatty Acid-Binding Protein (H-FABP)

(Option D)
  • It is the earliest marker to rise in a case of myocardial infarction (MI).
  • It has higher sensitivity than troponin and CK-MB for detecting AMI within 4 hours of symptom onset, but its specificity is lower.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient who underwent gastrointestinal surgery one month ago, presents with a palpable abdominal bulge at the surgical site. Physical examination reveals a reducible 12 cm incisional hernia. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe an abdominal belt for daily use
Advise observation and reassessment in six months

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Schedule for laparoscopic mesh repair

 

 

Explanation:

The gold standard treatment for an incisional hernia is intra-peritoneal onlay mesh repair.

  • Mesh repair is preferred because it significantly reduces the risk of recurrence compared to other methods.
  • An incisional hernia, also known as a post-operative ventral wall hernia, occurs when fascial tissues fail to fuse properly after surgery.

 

Incisional Hernia Mesh Placement Techniques:

Technique

Mesh Placement

Procedure

Advantages

Disadvantages

Inlay

Within the fascial defect itself

Mesh is sutured to the edges of the fascial defect.

It can be used for large defects where primary closure isn't possible.

High recurrence rates due to mesh separation from fascial edges under abdominal pressure

Onlay

On top of the anterior rectus sheath/external oblique aponeurosis

Subcutaneous tissue is dissected off; the fascial defect is closed primarily, and the mesh is placed on top and secured

Technically easier and less invasive.

Higher risk of seroma formation, mesh infection, and skin necrosis.

Retromuscular

 

Behind the rectus muscle but anterior to the posterior rectus sheath

The posterior rectus sheath is opened, the mesh is placed in the created space, and the posterior sheath is closed over it

Lower recurrence rates, mesh well incorporated into tissues

More complex procedure, risk of injury to neurovascular bundles.

Preperitoneal

 

Between the peritoneum and the posterior rectus sheath.

Peritoneum is separated from posterior rectus sheath, mesh is placed in this space, peritoneum is closed over it.

Good mesh incorporation, lower risk of adhesions.

Technically challenging, risk of peritoneal tears.

Incorrect Options:

Prescribe an abdominal belt for daily use (Option B): An abdominal belt may be prescribed temporarily for support and improved wound healing post-surgery, but it does not treat the hernia itself.

Advise observation and reassessment in six months (Option C): This approach is not recommended, as incisional hernias can lead to complications such as strangulation, obstruction, and incarceration if left untreated.

Laparoscopic closure without mesh (Option D) is not advisable due to higher recurrence rates associated with this approach. Mesh repair offers a more reliable long-term solution.

questions.text: A child with a strawberry skull, mental retardation, and the given karyotype suggests which diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Edward syndrome

Explanation:

A child with a "strawberry skull," intellectual disability, and the given karyotype likely has trisomy 18, indicating a diagnosis of Edwards Syndrome.

  • It is caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 18.
  • Clinical features:
    • Low birth weight
    • Strawberry skull (small chin & prominent occiput/back side of the head).
    • Closed fists with overlapping fingers
    • Rocker-bottom feet
    • Microcephaly
    • Micrognathia
    • Cardiac and renal malformations
    • Mental retardation
    • 95% of cases die in the 1st year of life

 

Patau syndrome (Option A), caused by trisomy 13, is characterised by features such as polydactyly (extra fingers), cleft lip and palate, keyhole-shaped pupils/coloboma, intellectual disability, and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), among others.

Prader-Willi syndrome (Option C) occurs when there is maternal disomy of chromosome 15, leading to the absence of the paternal allele. Key features include intellectual disability (MR), short stature, and obesity/hyperphagia due to elevated levels of the hormone ghrelin.


Angelman syndrome (Option D), often referred to as "Happy Puppet" syndrome, arises when there is a paternal disomy of chromosome 15, leading to the absence of the maternal allele. Key features include seizures, ataxia, intellectual disability (MR), and inappropriate laughter.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents for her annual checkup with no specific complaints. As part of preventive screening, which cancer screening test should be prioritized based on the most common malignancy affecting females?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mammogram

Explanation:

Breast cancer is the most common malignancy in females worldwide, making mammogram screening essential for early detection.

  • Mammography is the gold standard screening tool for breast cancer
  • Recommended starting at age 40-50 years (varies by guidelines)
  • Can detect tumors before they become clinically palpable

Pap Smear (Option B) is used to screen for cervical cancer, which is less common than breast cancer.

Transvaginal ultrasound (Option C) is used to evaluate pelvic organs, such as the ovaries and uterus, and is typically performed for symptomatic patients (e.g., pelvic pain or abnormal bleeding). It is not a standard screening tool for any specific cancer.

Colonoscopy (Option D) is used to screen colorectal cancer, which affects both genders and has lower incidence in females compared to breast cancer.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 presents in active labor at 39 weeks gestation. On examination, the fetus is in occiput posterior (OP) position with reassuring fetal heart tones. She had a previous uncomplicated vaginal delivery. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Proceed with normal vaginal delivery

Explanation:Occiput posterior (OP) position, while a malposition, does not automatically necessitate surgical intervention. Normal vaginal delivery should be attempted first in the absence of other complications.

  • OP position occurs in approximately 10% of vertex presentations
  • Most OP positions can successfully deliver vaginally
  • Fetal heart tones are typically heard more centrally due to fetal back position
  • Previous successful vaginal delivery is a positive prognostic factor

External cephalic version (Option C): External cephalic version (ECV) is a procedure that turns a breech baby into a head-down position. This procedure is used for breech presentations, not for OP position.

Immediate cesarean section (Option B): Not indicated for OP position. This would be overly aggressive management when vaginal delivery is often successful.

Forceps rotation (Option D): Should not be the initial management. It should only be considered if there's failure to progress after attempting vaginal delivery.

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with gastroschisis. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Surgical wall repair

Explanation:

  • Gastroschisis is a congenital defect where the baby is born with the intestines exposed through a hole in the abdominal wall. The most appropriate treatment is surgical wall repair, where the exposed intestines are placed back into the abdomen, and the defect is closed.

Feature

Omphalocele

Gastroschisis

Definition

Congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal contents protrude through the base of the umbilicus.

Congenital abdominal wall defect is when abdominal contents protrude through a defect typically located to the right of the umbilicus.

Covering

The herniated organs are covered by two layers: Amnion (outer) and peritoneum (inner).

No membrane covers the exposed organs.

Associated conditions
  • Chromosomal abnormalities: Associated with Trisomy 13, 18, and 21.
  • Other congenital malformations affect multiple systems in the following order: cardiovascular> Muscular> gastrointestinal> genitourinary. (Mnemonic: "CM GIGU")
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome: Can include hemihypertrophy, macroglossia, visceromegaly, omphalocele, and increased risk of hepatoblastoma.
  • Fewer chromosomal abnormalities compared to omphalocele.
  • Higher risk of intestinal atresia and dysfunction.

Prognosis

Generally poor due to associated congenital malformations, which are the most common cause of death.

Generally better than omphalocele due to fewer associated congenital anomalies.

Management
  • Primary surgical closure is preferred for small to medium-sized defects.
  • Larger defects may require:
  • Prosthetic patch closure (e.g., Gore-Tex),
  • Porcine small intestinal submucosa-derived biomaterials (e.g., Surgisis),
  • Skin flap closure, or
  • Placement of a silo for sequential reduction and staged closure.
  • For giant omphaloceles, topical application of escharotic agents like povidone-iodine (Betadine) ointment or silver nitrate is used to thicken and epithelialize the sac.
  • Primary closure is typically done under general anesthesia and often requires admission to the NICU for postoperative ventilation.
  • Alternatively, a preformed silo can be placed at the bedside for gradual reduction, sometimes avoiding the need for general anesthesia altogether.

 

Incorrect Options:

Wait and watch (Option B): This approach is not recommended as it can lead to complications such as fluid loss, hypothermia, hypovolemia, sepsis, metabolic acidosis, and necrotizing enterocolitis.

Slowly putting it inside (Option C): While the intestines are gradually pushed back inside during primary closure, this is not a management option by itself.

Surgical excision (Option D) is only performed for non-viable bowel followed by anastomosis.

questions.text: Identify the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Omphalocele

Explanation:

The given image shows Omphalocele.

Omphalocele is a central abdominal wall defect typically larger than 4 cm in diameter, characterized by an intact membranous sac composed of an outer layer of amnion and an inner layer of peritoneum. Defects smaller than 4 cm are classified as umbilical cord hernias.

  • Associated anomalies:
    • 50% of infants with omphalocele have associated anomalies, including:
      • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome: A combination of gigantism, macroglossia, and an umbilical defect (either hernia or omphalocele).
      • Chromosomal abnormalities such as trisomies 13, 15, 18, and 21.
      • Other conditions like bladder exstrophy, cloaca, and pentalogy of Cantrell, which includes:
        • Omphalocele
        • Anterior diaphragmatic hernia
        • Sternal cleft
        • Ectopia cordis
        • Intracardiac defects, like ventricular septal defect.
  • Initial management:
    • The presence of an intact omphalocele sac is crucial for initial management.
    • Preventing hypothermia is a primary concern.
    • A comprehensive diagnostic workup is performed to identify associated anomalies.
  • Surgical treatment:
    • Primary surgical closure is preferred for small to medium-sized defects.
    • Larger defects may require:
      • Prosthetic patch closure (e.g., Gore-Tex),
      • Porcine small intestinal submucosa-derived biomaterials (e.g., Surgisis),
      • Skin flap closure, or
      • Placement of a silo for sequential reduction and staged closure.
    • For giant omphaloceles, topical application of escharotic agents like povidone-iodine (Betadine) ointment or silver nitrate is used to thicken and epithelialize the sac.
  • The overall survival of infants with omphalocele depends largely on their lung maturity and the severity of associated anomalies.

 

Urachal cyst (Option B) is a fluid-filled sac that results from the incomplete closure of the urachus (a remnant of the connection between the bladder and the umbilical cord). It doesn't present as an abdominal wall defect like omphalocele.

Umbilical hernia (Option C) occurs when part of the intestine or other abdominal contents protrude through the umbilical opening in the abdominal muscles. It’s usually smaller and has no sac covering the contents, as seen in omphalocele.

Umbilical adenoma (Option D) is a benign tumour located in or near the umbilicus, unrelated to abdominal wall defects like omphalocele.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with cervical lymphadenopathy. A biopsy has revealed granulomatous necrotising inflammation. Which of the following options is correct?

choices.text: Metastatic calcification with normal serum calcium level
Dystrophic calcification with normal serum calcium level
Metastatic calcification with increased serum calcium level
Dystrophic calcification with increased serum calcium level

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dystrophic calcification with normal serum calcium level

Explanation:

The scenario suggests tuberculosis, marked by cervical lymphadenopathy and granulomatous necrotising inflammation, in which Dystrophic Calcification with normal serum calcium levels can be seen.

Dystrophic Calcification:

  • It involves the deposition of calcium salts in damaged or abnormal tissues rather than normal tissues.
  • Serum calcium is normal. (Option D ruled out)
  • It is present in the atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis and develops in ageing or damaged heart valves.
  • Macroscopically, the calcium salts appear fine, and white granules or clumps often feel like gritty deposits.
  • Microscopically, calcium salts have a basophilic, amorphous granular, and sometimes clumped appearance.
  • Psammoma bodies are small, round, laminated, calcific structures that resemble onion peels.
  • They can be seen in Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid and kidney, Prolactinoma, Serous ovarian carcinoma, Meningioma, and Mesothelioma.
  • Other examples are:
    • Tuberculosis (Option B) (Option C ruled out)
    • Atheroma
    • Dead parasite
    • Monckeberg Sclerosis

Metastatic calcification may occur in normal tissues whenever there is hypercalcemia. (Option A ruled out)

There are four principal causes of hypercalcemia:

  1. Increased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH): Hyperparathyroidism (parathyroid tumours) and ectopic secretion of PTH-related protein (malignant tumours).
  2. Resorption of bone tissue, secondary to primary tumours of bone marrow (e.g., multiple myeloma, leukaemia) or diffuse skeletal metastasis (e.g., breast cancer), accelerated bone turnover (e.g., Paget disease), or immobilisation.
  3. Vitamin D–related disorders, including vitamin D intoxication, sarcoidosis, and idiopathic hypercalcemia of infancy (Williams syndrome).
  4. Renal failure, which causes retention of phosphate (Secondary hyperparathyroidism).

Less common causes include aluminium intoxication, which occurs in patients on chronic renal dialysis, and milk-alkali syndrome, which is due to excessive ingestion of calcium and absorbable antacids such as milk or calcium carbonate.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bulbar urethral stricture

Explanation:

  • The image shows a micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU), which reveals a bulbar urethral stricture.
  • The most common cause of urethral stricture is trauma, often due to external forces like an external blow, kick, or straddle injuries (e.g., falling onto a hard object like a manhole).
  • Bulbar urethral injury falls under anterior urethral injury, and retrograde urethrogram (RGU) is the investigation of choice for such injuries. However, both RGU and MCU are often performed in emergency cases.

Male Urethra: Fibromuscular tube extending from the bladder neck to the meatus and functions to transport urine and semen.

  • Posterior urethra: Prostatic urethra and membranous urethra.
  • Anterior urethra: Bulbar urethra, Penile urethra, and Urethral meatus.
  • Urethral Meatus: Vertical slit-like opening at the tip of the glans penis.
  • Glandular Urethra, also known as the fossa navicularis.
  • Penile Urethra: Extends from the meatus to the penoscrotal junction. The longest part of the urethra
  • Bulbar Urethra: Extends from the penoscrotal junction to the bulbomembranous junction.
  • Membranous Urethra: Extends from the bulbomembranous junction to the verumontanum. The shortest, narrowest, and least dilated part is innervated by the pudendal nerve from spinal segments S2-4.
  • Prostatic Urethra: Extends from the bladder neck to the verumontanum and is surrounded by the prostate. The widest and most dilatable part of the urethra.

Feature

Anterior Urethral Injury

Posterior Urethral Injury

Location
  • Bulbar urethra (most common)
  • Penile urethra
  • Membranous urethra (bulbomembranous junction most common)
  • Prostatic urethra

 

Common Causes
  • Straddle injuries
  • Direct trauma
  • Iatrogenic injuries (catheterization, cystoscopy)
  • Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds)
  • Pelvic fractures (often due to motor vehicle accidents)
  • Blunt trauma

Clinical Features
  • Hematuria (blood in urine)
  • Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma)
  • Perineal pain
  • Urinary retention or difficulty voiding
  • Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma
  • Blood at the meatus
  • Inability to void
  • High-riding prostate on rectal exam
  • Perineal or suprapubic pain
  • Pelvic hematoma associated with pelvic fractures
  • Possible concomitant bladder injury

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard, shows the extent and location of the injury.
  • Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair
  • Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment
  • CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries
  • Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures
  • Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation
  • If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance

Incorrect Options:

Membranous urethral injury (Option B) This refers to a posterior urethral injury, which typically occurs further up the urethra and is different from anterior injuries like bulbar urethral stricture.

Urethral tear (Option C) is typically seen as a focal area of contrast extravasation or leakage outside the normal urethral lumen, which is not the case in this stricture.

Prostate hyperplasia (Option D) is marked by an enlarged transition zone in imaging studies like MRI, not related to urethral stricture.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is pneumomediastinum commonly found?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Boerhaave syndrome

Explanation:

  • Pneumomediastinum is one of the complication associated with Boerhaave syndrome, which is a condition characterized by spontaneous full-thickness rupture of the esophagus.
  • Boerhaave syndrome clinically manifests as Mackler’s triad (Vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema). The condition is often preceded by forceful vomiting.
  • This condition typically occurs in the lower third of the esophagus and results in a direct communication between the esophageal lumen and mediastinal space. The rupture allows esophageal contents to spill into the mediastinum which can occasionally lead to complications such as pneumomediastinum and chemical mediastinitis.

 

Boerhaave syndrome

Definition

It is a spontaneous esophageal rupture caused by a sudden increase in intraesophageal pressure, typically from vomiting against a closed glottis resulting in a left-sided esophageal perforation, which allows gastric contents to spill into the pleural cavity, leading to a left pleural effusion and subcutaneous emphysema.

Classic triad

Vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema. (Mackler’s triad)

Other Symptoms

May include fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea in the presence of sepsis

Physical examination

Hamman’s sign (crunching sound on auscultation due to surgical emphysema).

Complications

Pneumothorax/Pneumomediastinum, mediastinitis, and sepsis.

 

Pulsion diverticulum (Option A) occurs due to increased intraluminal pressure in the esophagus, forming an outpouching of the esophageal wall. While it can cause symptoms like dysphagia and regurgitation, it does not typically result in pneumomediastinum as the esophageal wall remains intact.

Mallory-Weiss syndrome (Option C) involves longitudinal mucosal tears at the gastroesophageal junction, typically following forceful vomiting. While it can cause hematemesis, the tear is superficial and does not extend through the full thickness of the esophageal wall, thus not causing pneumomediastinum.

Pericarditis (Option D) is inflammation of the pericardium, the fibrous sac surrounding the heart. While it causes chest pain and other symptoms related to inflammation, it does not involve the esophagus and does not cause pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: Which of the following organs is a primary lymphoid organ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thymus

Explanation:

The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ.

Lymphoid Organs are structures involved in the production, maturation, and storage of immune cells, essential for the immune system to detect and respond to pathogens.

  • They are classified as:
    • Primary lymphoid organ (Development and maturation of T and B lymphocytes)
    • Secondary lymphoid organ (Site of adaptive immune responses to antigens)

Primary Lymphoid Organs

Secondary Lymphoid Organs

Bone Marrow:

  • Origin of all blood cells from pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells (a process called hematopoiesis).
  • Hematopoiesis shifts to bone marrow from the liver after fetal life, eventually confined to axial bones after puberty.
  • Progenitor T and B cells develop in bone marrow; B cells mature here, while T cell progenitors migrate to the thymus.

Lymph Nodes: (Option A ruled out)

  • Filter antigens and activate T and B cells.
  • Structured into cortex (B cell area), paracortex (T cell area), and medulla (rich in plasma cells).

Spleen: (Option B ruled out)

  • Largest secondary lymphoid organ, involved in filtering blood-borne antigens.
  • Contains white pulp (T and B cells) and red pulp (site of RBC destruction).

Thymus: (Option C)

  • Site of T cell proliferation and maturation.
  • Developed from the third/fourth pharyngeal pouch in embryonic life.
  • Active during childhood, decreases in size after puberty.
  • Thymic hormones (e.g., thymulin, thymopoietin) help attract and mature T cells.
  • Central tolerance occurs here, removing self-reactive T cells to prevent autoimmunity.

Mucosa-associated Lymphoid Tissue (MALT): (Option D ruled out)

  • Located in mucosal sites (intestine, respiratory, urogenital tracts) to protect against pathogens.
  • Includes loose clusters of lymphoid cells and organised structures (e.g., tonsils, Peyer’s patches in intestines).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man experiences initial paralysis in both legs, which then progresses to affect both upper limbs as well. Over time, he shows slight improvement in upper limbs but no improvement in his lower trunk and both legs. Based on this description, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diplegia

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate diplegia, a condition characterized by symmetric paralysis that predominantly affects the lower body while sparing or minimally affecting the upper limbs.
  • The patient's clinical course shows an initial widespread paralysis that improved to primarily affect the lower trunk and legs, and only slight involvement of upper limbs, which is characteristic of diplegia.

 

Quadriplegia (Option B) refers to paralysis of all four limbs and typically includes the torso. While the patient initially experienced widespread involvement, the final clinical picture with predominant lower body involvement does not correlate with quadriplegia.

Paraplegia (Option C) involves complete paralysis of the lower half of the body, including both legs, but does not affect the arms. The patient's history of upper limb involvement and subsequent improvement makes paraplegia an incorrect diagnosis.

Monoplegia (Option D) refers to paralysis affecting only one limb. The patient's presentation with bilateral leg and lower trunk involvement clearly indicates a more extensive pattern of paralysis than monoplegia.

questions.text: A patient develops a severe infection and necrosis in the scrotal region after 5 days of catheterization. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fournier’s gangrene

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation suggests Fournier's gangrene, a severe soft tissue infection involving the perineum. This condition is typically caused by a mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection.
  • This condition is characterised by a mixed infection involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.
  • The most common aerobic microorganisms include Escherichia coli, Proteus, Staphylococcus, Klebsiella, and Streptococcus. The predominant anaerobic microorganisms are Bacteroides, Clostridium, and Peptostreptococcus.

Fournier's Gangrene

Definition
  • Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through

five phases:

    • Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy.
    • Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible edema, pruritus.
    • Progressive Phase: Increased pain, and erythema.
    • Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation.
    • Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge.
  • Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses.
  • Severity ranges from localized tenderness to septic shock.

Risk Factors
  • Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism, immunocompromised states.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings.

Management
  • Initial Treatment:
    • Fluid resuscitation.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue.
  • Additional Measures:
    • Urinary and faecal diversion to prevent wound contamination.
    • Intensive monitoring for sepsis.
    • Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing.
    • Skin grafting post-infection control.

Incorrect Options:

Gas gangrene (Option B) is a severe infectious condition caused by clostridial organisms, primarily affecting skeletal muscle and leading to edematous myonecrosis.

Wet gangrene (Option C) refers to a form of necrosis associated with bacterial infection and rapid tissue death, but the term is not specific to the genital area.

Scrotal hematoma (Option D) usually results from damage to the venous structures due to trauma, testicular torsion, inguinal hernia, or other injuries.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a painless testicular mass. After orchidectomy, histopathological examination reveals the presence of Reinke's crystals within the tumor cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Leydig cell tumor

Explanation:

  • Reinke's Crystals are typically seen in Leydig cell tumors, which is a type of sex cord-stromal tumor.

Sexcord stromal tumors:

 

Leydig cell tumour

Sertoli cell tumor (Option A ruled out)

Hormonal involvement

It often involves androgens, estrogens, and corticosteroids.

Hormonally silent.

Conditions associated with
  • Klinefelter syndrome.
  • Cryptorchidism.
  • Renal cell carcinoma.
  • Carney complex.
  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis.

Malignancy

10% (in adults)

10%

Gross
  • Circumscribed nodules, usually < 5 cm in diameter.
  • They have a distinctive golden brown, homogeneous appearance on cut surfaces.
  • Firm, small nodules with a homogeneous
  • grey-white to yellow cut surface.

Histology
  • The tumour cells resemble their normal counterparts.
  • They are large and have round or polygonal cell outlines, abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm, and a round central nucleus.
  • The cytoplasm frequently contains lipid droplets, vacuoles, or lipofuscin pigment and, most characteristically, rod-shaped Reinke crystalloids (25% of the tumors).
  • The tumour cells are arranged in distinctive trabeculae that tend to form cord-like structures and tubules.

 

Image

Seminoma: (Option C ruled out)

  • Reinke's Crystals are not present in seminomas.
  • Seminoma is the most common testicular tumour, typically seen in the 3rd and 4th decades of life.
  • Tumor markers associated with seminomas include beta-HCG, which is commonly elevated, along with markers related to disease bulk, such as:
    • LDH
    • PLAP
    • GGT

Yolk sac tumor: (Option D ruled out)

  • The tumor marker for yolk sac tumors is alpha-fetoprotein.
  • Yolk sac tumors are the most common testicular tumors in children, particularly between 1-3 years of age.
  • Yolk sac tumors are also associated with the best prognosis among testicular tumors.

questions.text: A patient presents with calf pain while walking a certain distance. The pain is severe enough that he must stop and rest before continuing. According to Boyd's grading, which of the following grades best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grade 3

Explanation:

  • Grade III is characterised by pain that persists during walking, and the patient has to stop and rest to relieve the pain.

Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication:

Grade

Description

Grade I

Pain develops after walking a certain distance (claudication distance). The pain subsides due to increased blood flow and collateral circulation.

Grade II

Pain persists even while continuing to walk, but the patient can still walk with effort.

Grade III

Patient must stop and rest to relieve the pain; walking becomes significantly impaired.

Grade IV

Patient experiences rest pain, and the pain persists even at rest, indicating severe arterial disease.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room after a road traffic accident with shock and hypotension. The extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is negative, the X-ray is normal, and the ECG shows no abnormalities. The patient's SpO2 is 93%, blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, and pulse rate is 40/min. Based on this information, what type of shock is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Neurogenic shock

Explanation:

  • Neurogenic shock is characterized by hypotension, bradycardia (low pulse rate), and normal or slightly reduced SpO2. The absence of trauma to solid organs, negative eFAST, and normal X-rays help rule out hemorrhagic or cardiogenic shock. The bradycardia (pulse of 40/min) is due to a loss of sympathetic tone following spinal cord injury or severe trauma, leading to vasodilation and bradycardia.

Neurogenic shock:

  • In neurogenic shock, there is a loss of sympathetic tone, leading to vasodilation of the peripheral vasculature, resulting in decreased peripheral vascular resistance and hypotension. This is the primary mechanism underlying neurogenic shock.

Causes:

  • Neurogenic shock is a critical condition that results from the dysregulation of the autonomic nervous system following spinal cord injury, especially in the cervical and upper thoracic vertebrae above the T6 level, as a result of traumatic events. The dysregulation arises due to the lack of sympathetic tone and decreased peripheral vascular resistance.
  • The decline in sympathetic tone prompts the dilation of capacitance blood vessels in the lower extremities. This, in turn, results in decreased cardiac filling, leading to hypotension and shock.
  • Reduced sympathetic control over the heart leads to a situation where unopposed vagal cardiac influence causes bradycardia.
  • Patients with neurogenic shock may also exhibit pink and warm skin due to the dilation of subcutaneous blood vessels.
  • Severe brain injury.
  • Certain anaesthetics.

Pathophysiology

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia (unlike other forms of shock)
  • Warm, dry skin below injury level
  • Priapism in males
  • Respiratory compromise (if high cervical injury)
  • Poikilothermia (inability to regulate body temperature)

Physiological Hemodynamic Characteristics of Shock

Type of Shock

Cardiac Output

Systemic Vascular Resistance

Central Venous Pressure

Mean Arterial Pressure

Hypovolemic

↓

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents with episodes of chest pain. Physical examination reveals a bisferiens pulse and a heaving apex. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

Explanation:

  • The presence of a bisferiens pulse (double-peaked pulse) and a heaving apex are characteristic physical findings of Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM).
  • This condition is characterized by asymmetric hypertrophy of the ventricular septum, which can cause dynamic obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract.

 

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

Feature

Characteristics

Pathophysiology
  • Autosomal dominant genetic disorder
  • Mutations in beta-myosin heavy-chain, troponin, and myosin-binding protein C
  • Inappropriate left ventricular hypertrophy

Key Physical Findings
  • Bisferiens (jerky arterial) pulse
  • Heaving apex
  • Mid-systolic murmur
  • Dynamic LVOT obstruction

Common Symptoms
  • Angina (chest pain)
  • Dyspnea
  • Syncope
  • MC cause of sudden death

Pathological Features
  • Misaligned myocardial fibers
  • Myocardial fibrosis
  • Rigid left ventricle
  • Impaired diastolic filling

Examination Findings

Clinical Finding

Description

Palpable Left Ventricular Hypertrophy

An enlarged left ventricle can be felt during physical examination, indicating hypertrophy.

Double Impulse at the Apex

A palpable fourth heart sound suggests forceful atrial contraction against a non-compliant ventricle.

Mid-Systolic Murmur at the Base

Turbulent blood flow through the obstructed left ventricular outflow tract produces a mid-systolic murmur.

Pansystolic Murmur at the Apex

Indicates mitral regurgitation caused by abnormal systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve.

Jerky Arterial Pulse

Characteristic of HOCM, contrasts with the slow-rising pulse seen in aortic stenosis.

Pulsus bisferiens

A double pulse noticed during systole in the peripheral pulse is called pulsus bisferiens. It is associated with severe aortic disease accompanied by aortic regurgitation and HOCM.

 

 

 

Dilated Cardiomyopathy (Option A) is characterized by left ventricular dilation and impaired systolic function. Physical exam findings typically include signs of heart failure, such as elevated jugular venous pressure and displaced apex beat, but bisferiens pulse and heaving apex are not typical features.

Mitral Stenosis (Option C) presents with obstruction of blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle. Physical exam findings typically include a diastolic murmur best heard at the apex and possible signs of left atrial enlargement, but bisferiens pulse is not a characteristic finding.

Aortic Stenosis (Option D) causes obstruction of blood flow from the left ventricle into the aorta. While it can present with chest pain, the classic physical findings include a systolic ejection murmur and a reduced or delayed carotid pulse, not a bisferiens pulse.

questions.text: In patients at risk of refeeding syndrome, which of the following electrolyte imbalances is typically not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hyperkalemia

Explanation:

Hyperkalemia is not typically associated with refeeding syndrome. In fact, potassium levels usually decrease during refeeding, contributing to hypokalemia.

Refeeding syndrome:

  • One of the most significant metabolic complications of both parenteral and enteral feeding.
  • This occurs in the first days after feeding is commenced in patients who have been severely malnourished.

The patient is considered to be at risk of developing refeeding syndrome with EITHER.

One or more of the following: (OR)

Two or more of the following:

BMI <16 kg/m2

BMI <18.5 kg/m2

Unintentional weight loss >15% within the last 3-6 months

Unintentional weight loss >10% within the last 3-6 months.

Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days

Little or no nutritional intake for more than 5 days.

Low potassium, phosphate or magnesium levels prior to feeding

History of alcohol abuse or on medication, including insulin, chemotherapy, antacids or diuretics.

 

Mechanism of Refeeding Syndrome:

Electrolyte abnormalities:

  • Hypophosphatemia (Option D)
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalemia (Option A)
  • Hypocalcemia (Option C)

This leads to arrhythmia, confusion, and respiratory failure, ultimately leading to death.

Management:

  • Matching the intake with requirements.
  • Avoid overfeeding
  • Calorie delivery should be increased slowly
  • Vitamin administration (Thiamine): Given before feeding.
  • Electrolyte abnormalities should be corrected
